title_review: Great food at a relaxed pace
review_preview: This is definitely not the place to go if you are in a hurry. But if you want excellent food at a reasonable (not cheap) price, it's worth the time. We were a little put off at first because our waitress was gruff and a...
review_full: This is definitely not the place to go if you are in a hurry. But if you want excellent food at a reasonable (not cheap) price, it's worth the time. We were a little put off at first because our waitress was gruff and a bit cranky, but it was probably just the press of customers and the sight of what she must have assumed were more picky, unadventurous Americans. Once we sat down and started asking for her advice and saying, "That sounds great, let's try that," she warmed up considerably. She did warn us that we were ordering too much food, but did we listen? No. And we were happy with everything that arrived on the table. I'd eat here once a week or more if I lived nearby.

review_preview: Stopped here for an excellent Friday lunch. Good unpretentious food surrounded by Madrid locals.We had the three course Menu del Dia for 12 Euros each. Food is simple home cooking done well. For starters we had ham croquettes and a salad.  For mains we...
review_full: Stopped here for an excellent Friday lunch. Good unpretentious food surrounded by Madrid locals. We had the three course Menu del Dia for 12 Euros each. Food is simple home cooking done well. For starters we had ham croquettes and a salad. For mains we had cheese covered bull caneloni and chicken in red wine. Service was efficient and business - like. Despite the rather plain decor inside there was quite a warm and welcoming atmosphere. If you are near Plaza Mayor this is a much cheaper and less touristy option than the mass of offerings on the square.

title_review: An oasis in the touristy desert
review_preview: Skip all those places in the nearby Plaza Mayor where hawkers try to talk you into sitting down right then and there, and instead find your way to this out-of-the-way, unpretentious wonder of a restaurant. It's actually not that hard to find, as it's behind...
review_full: Skip all those places in the nearby Plaza Mayor where hawkers try to talk you into sitting down right then and there, and instead find your way to this out-of-the-way, unpretentious wonder of a restaurant. It's actually not that hard to find, as it's behind the Mercado de San Miguel, a big, gaudy, glass and iron structure full of people and food markets. Get a taxi to take you to Mercado de San Miguel, or Plaza de San Miguel, and then walk around the Mercado until you find Emma's. There are actually two Emma's, I think run by the same lady, in close proximity to each other (the other is more of a bar, but also has food). We decide on this one. We had four tapas dishes, all with unique twists, nothing like the commodity tapas you get in the surrounding area. One was potatoes steamed and served "Canary Island" style, with two sauces for dipping; another, our favourite, was a lightly fried, crunchy and honey-sweetened then eggplant slices. A tapas portion of the lamb tagine was a big hit with my wife, and a selection of Iberian cold meats was authentic, flavourful, and delicious. Servings were all generous, incredible, really, for the price. We also found a wonderful wine there, a 2011 tinto from Ribera del Duero, just about their most expensive bottle for only 25€. The entire dinner, including wine, came to a mere 60€. Amazing place. You must go there. Get there a little early, say 9 PM, because it's small and gets busy later...

review_preview: We had one night in Madrid, and were staying nearby.  Reviews had led us here, and WOW was it a fantastic meal.  It was a little hard to find, but we were glad we persisted.  The staff didn't speak much English, but had an English-language...
review_full: We had one night in Madrid, and were staying nearby. Reviews had led us here, and WOW was it a fantastic meal. It was a little hard to find, but we were glad we persisted. The staff didn't speak much English, but had an English-language menu and worked with good humor to understand what we wanted. Every course was unbelievably good, and expertly prepared. They paired a red wine with it for me that was a perfect complement. The total bill, including wine, was about US$80 for the four of us. It also felt like a local place; I think only one other table seemed to be out-of-town people, with families and couples filling most of the other tables in this small space. A phenomenal meal that we will long remember!

review_preview: i love botin and all sorts of other bars etc in madrid, but la revuelta is the purest and most authentic tapas bar experience you can have. the two times we were there, we were the ONLY non-locals there. it's tiny. you squeeze in and...
review_full: i love botin and all sorts of other bars etc in madrid, but la revuelta is the purest and most authentic tapas bar experience you can have. the two times we were there, we were the ONLY non-locals there. it's tiny. you squeeze in and try to get a place at the stainless steel bar or at one of the three tiny tables, otherwise you just stand. the floor is covered in the shells of the salt-crusted peanuts they serve everyone in little sacks, which are also all over the floor. sort of like sawdust in a cowboy bar, but authentic, not just for effect. you drink small glasses of cold mahou beer or red wine, and you eat the best deep-fried salt cod (bacalao) you will ever have anywhere. it's one of the world's great foods, and i've had it in the best places for it in lisbon, in rome, anywhere i can get it. but this is simply the best. delicious crust, tender and succulent bacalao. it's hard to stop. but you can take a break and have the deep fried chunks of pork belly (torreznos), another revelation. the second time we were there, after our first order of bacalao, we wanted to order more, but the waiter said no, we had to have the calamari, a special that day, because it was so good (this is what we understood). we expected fried calamari, but no, we got a plate of cut pieces of squid braised in their own ink. a little surprising at first (my daughter loves it, but i've always been a bit more hesitant about it); she said i had to try it, so i did, and it was unbelievably good. then we had some more bacalao, so torreznos, some more bacalao. it's just the best. in fact, i'm a little hesitant to tell y'all about it, because i want it to stay just as it is.

review_preview: A small old family bar with no pretensions in the heart of Madrid, between Plaza Mayor and Plaza de la Villa, which is always full of locals any day of the week and, despite its modest appearance (with small tables and wooden benches) is one...
review_full: A small old family bar with no pretensions in the heart of Madrid, between Plaza Mayor and Plaza de la Villa, which is always full of locals any day of the week and, despite its modest appearance (with small tables and wooden benches) is one of the best kept secrets of the city, a wonderful taste "tapa" of codfish. The codfish is the "tapa" that everyone comes to eat, and from early in the morning in the kitchen they strive to prepare it coated with a thin layer of flour and lightly fried in good olive oil. Without a single spine and always freshly made, if you eat it with a rod (glass of beer) or the traditional vermouth, it becomes a form of a delicious aperitif. Its very tight cost 5.50 euros for a glass of beer and two pieces of codfish (one it's never enough) make this a must for our visit to the old city center.

title_review: Soak up the atmosphere and the excellent cod
review_preview: This small, cramped and unassuming bar is close to the Plaza Mayor. Indeed, it is always packed with madrileños - even on a weekday just after 19.00 when it reopens for the evening shift - and yet there always seems to be standing room to...
review_full: This small, cramped and unassuming bar is close to the Plaza Mayor. Indeed, it is always packed with madrileños - even on a weekday just after 19.00 when it reopens for the evening shift - and yet there always seems to be standing room to enjoy a delicious chunk of salt cod fried lightly in batter. Salt is a misnomer as it is not at all salty after soaking in cold water for at least 24 hours or more ;-) The small glass of red wine (apparently from Valdepeñas) that people order with it is a pretty indifferent house wine. A caña of draught lager is probably a better bet. The bar service was fast, friendly and efficient. Our two large pieces of ´bacalao’, a wine and a beer came to 7.50 euro which is good value for a place which serves some of the best cod in Madrid.

review_preview: Don't be put off by reviews saying Revuelta is cramped and the barmen unfriendly. Beers here are 1 euro, a Vermut is around 2 euros. Yes, there is no obvious price list but it is so reasonable why would you need it? Order the bacalao...
review_full: Don't be put off by reviews saying Revuelta is cramped and the barmen unfriendly. Beers here are 1 euro, a Vermut is around 2 euros. We loved it so much we returned three nights on the trot. Barmen will respond well to tourists who at least try to order in Spanish! It is always full of people but people come and go quickly so you should get a space at the bar in no time!

review_preview: The place is packed. Almost always. Pay no heed. Just squeeze on in and order a vino tint (glass of red wine) or a caña (small glass of beer). You might get some freshly fried pork rinds as a tapa (torreznos). Now order your salt...
review_full: The place is packed. Almost always. Pay no heed. Just squeeze on in and order a vino tint (glass of red wine) or a caña (small glass of beer). You might get some freshly fried pork rinds as a tapa (torreznos). Now order your salt cod (bacalao). Madrileños know that the chief competitor of this place, Casa Labra, up off Puerta del Sol, has gone downhill, alas, while at Casa Revuelta the bacalao is still top notch. Juicy, not mushy, light batter, and NO BONES. I guess it is statistically possible you'll get a bone or something (the fish all have them) but I've never met anyone who has.  Don't expect to sit down at a table (there are only 3 or 4). Do enjoy yourself in the multitude!

title_review: Love this place and good for vegetarian food too!
review_preview: We really enjoyed visiting Emma's Cocina - so much so we went twice during our trip. It's tucked away behind the market, close to Plaza Mayor. Service was timely, but with plenty of time to relax between dishes. The menu is interesting and varied and...
review_full: We really enjoyed visiting Emma's Cocina - so much so we went twice during our trip. It's tucked away behind the market, close to Plaza Mayor. Service was timely, but with plenty of time to relax between dishes. The menu is interesting and varied and a bit different from the usual tapas on offer. There was good vegetarian choice - loved the smoked cheese with mango and salsa verde and the spinach parcels were great. Lots of meat and fish on offer too with thoughtful suggestions from the waiter (who was really friendly). It's a small place, by 9pm the restaurant was full - lots of Spanish families as well as tourists. I would definitely recommend a visit - super!

review_preview: I highly recommend this place. Situated in a busy restaurant area in town, this place is not to be missed if you want to try a diverse menu as far as the main dishes are concerned. It was really heartening to see lots of locals...
review_full: I highly recommend this place. Situated in a busy restaurant area in town, this place is not to be missed if you want to try a diverse menu as far as the main dishes are concerned. It was really heartening to see lots of locals eat here as well and there are no staff pouncing on you as you walk by, handing out picture menus offering calamari or pork chops with chips. The Salmorejo was absolutely delicious and filling if eaten as a racione and not tapa. Also high on the list was the Oxtail stew, the tagine, the fish' meatballs' , and the Aubergine slices cooked Cordoban style.The service was friendly, efficient and the overall vibe was very enjoyable.

review_preview: We went to Emma Cocina's as we simply wanted to find a place that served good fresh burgers and it was the first one from a number we had seen reviewed in TA that we came across.The exterior and decor were unpromising at first....
review_full: We went to Emma Cocina's as we simply wanted to find a place that served good fresh burgers and it was the first one from a number we had seen reviewed in TA that we came across. The exterior and decor were unpromising at first. But the service was relaxed and friendly.  Based on another reviewers recommendation we had the mini burgers with caramelised onions and they were gorgeous.  We stayed for dessert as we were enjoying the vibe and the brownies and apple pie were not special but very tasty. I think eating out reviews all come down to "was it a yes feeling or no feeling"..and for us it was a yes we enjoyed the visit and would come back . If I were the owners I would add a few small touches externally and internally to draw in more tourists but that is a small thing and there is a danger it would lose its simple charm. Good simple food at reasonable prices .

review_preview: Most places offering tapas aren't very original. They offer the same old stuff and don't stray far from the beaten path. Emma Coccina, thankfully, dares to be different. You won't find the usual fare like albondigas, patatas bravas, etc. here. It even puts non-spanish dishes...
review_full: Most places offering tapas aren't very original. They offer the same old stuff and don't stray far from the beaten path. Emma Coccina, thankfully, dares to be different. You won't find the usual fare like albondigas, patatas bravas, etc. here. It even puts non-spanish dishes on its menu, like excellents koftas for example. Another thing that speaks in Emma Coccina's favour is that there are plenty vegetarian options on the menu. All in all we had our best meal of our holiday here. Pay this place a visit.

Appetizer of roasted red peppers also really good. Dessert was a selection of 3 types (all delicious), and because it was my birthday, they added a candle and a split of champagne at no charge. Service was great, ambiance amazing. It was more expensive than many Madrid restaurants, but absolutely worth every penny. For a special occasion while in Madrid, it is the best.

Well not much has changed apart from the prices. The decor, service and food is still the same - all very good. We ordered the lamb for our main course which was succulent and delicious and the house wine at under 10 euros for half a bottle was very good value. However, what was really disappointing is that they charged us 2.50 euros for 1 small packet of butter (which we asked for) on top of the 3.60 euros we paid for 2 small bread rolls and a few olives (which we did not order). Charging for the butter was exhorbitant and it has put me off going there again, as there are many excellent dining houses in Madrid and next time I am there I shall certainly give this restaurant a miss.

review_preview: Having been to the Rollerie located near Plaza Benavente and never been particularly impressed by it (nice settings but bored waiters and even more boring tea and pastries), I was super surprised by this outlet. Despite being in a rather touristy and busy location, the...
review_full: Having been to the Rollerie located near Plaza Benavente and never been particularly impressed by it (nice settings but bored waiters and even more boring tea and pastries), I was super surprised by this outlet. Despite being in a rather touristy and busy location, the waiters are super friendly and cheerful and even make an effort to understand foreign languages (rather than simply telling customers that they “don’t understand” like so many others in Madrid always do). Due to this and the cute décor, the atmosphere is super welcoming and makes for a great place to go for breakfast in the morning. As if that wasn’t enough, the prices are also really reasonable and there’s a pretty big range of things to choose from, both sweet and savory. Perhaps the best thing about this place, however, is that they even have a “vegan” breakfast on the menu for only 3 euros. Although the standard Spanish breakfast is already pretty much vegan (toasted bread with tomato paste and olive oil), La Rollerie takes it a step further and uses wholegrain vegan croissants to ensure that no animal products are used, hence making things even more interesting and original. Additionally, their tomato paste is orange in color and must therefore feature some other unique ingredients. Margarine and jam are also available as options to use on toast and therefore make this a place that is affordable and convenient for literally everyone.

review_full: I rarely rate a restaurant 5 stars, but this place just couldn't mess up the 2 times I came here. First off, I was immediately sat when I walked in, given a menu and poured water. I was given a minute or two and they were there to take my drink order. Another minute or two, my coffee was there and then my food order. Within minutes, our food rolled out. It tasted great and was filling. I asked for the check, it was brought to me and the prices were very reasonable. If that doesn't sum up an excellent dining experience, I don't know what does. If you're looking for a good tasting breakfast for a reasonable price, that is served very quickly, than this is your place. I can't speak for any other time of day besides breakfast.

title_review: The best seafood paella and grilled red prawns
review_preview: Paella is Spain's most recognizable dish. This rice dish is quite versatile as it can be filled with any number of tasty ingredients, like meat, seafood, and veggies. Every Spanish mother has their own recipe...you can try this excellent traditional mixed seafood paella in this...
review_full: Paella is Spain's most recognizable dish. This rice dish is quite versatile as it can be filled with any number of tasty ingredients, like meat, seafood, and veggies. Every Spanish mother has their own recipe...you can try this excellent traditional mixed seafood paella in this restaurant.  I tried panelle at difference restaurants in Madrid, Barcelona and and Seville. And this restaurant definitely offers the best seafood paella. It's extremely fresh and perfectly cooked and the seafood still unbelievablely yummy after cooking paella. Especially the shrimp, it's super! Besides ordering seafood panelle, deep fried red prawns also out of the world but it's more expensive than most of the place. Around Euro 15 each piece. I highly recommend you to try the seafood paella and red prawns here if you come to Madrid , if you don't like these two dishes, all seafoods are good and fresh here . Don't miss this! Don't forget to reserve a table if you want to eat after 9pm.

If you have a weak stomache maybe you should go find somewhere else that wouldnt have meat chopping scenes and fish smell. I didnt mind it if it meant for good food. Plus all the restaurants and cafes inside the mercado have the prettiest interiors and honestly it means that their ingredients are fresh from the markets right next to them.  I got a YAKISOBA noddle dish and a couple pieces of sushi. Unfortunately uni is only available in the winter so that wasnt available. The staff are very friendly. Don't be afraid to ask for the wifi password. They speak good English and don't wait for the check, because you go to the cashier to pay. Anyways I am sad to say that the food is not amazing. Maybe I had a high expectations from what people wrote and got too hyped up.

review_preview: Having been here a few times already (as well as other Japanese restaurants) I can definitely say that Yokaloka offers some of the best Japanese food in the city. Although it’s not super cheap, it’s still pretty affordable and definitely much better than in most...
review_full: Having been here a few times already (as well as other Japanese restaurants) I can definitely say that Yokaloka offers some of the best Japanese food in the city. Although it’s not super cheap, it’s still pretty affordable and definitely much better than in most places. Besides the delicious food and drinks, Yokaloka also happens to have helpful and efficient staff that actually makes an effort to smile and be polite towards their customers (even if they sometimes still look like they’d rather be doing something else). My only problem with this place, however, is its location. Although I’ve never been a fan of markets, I can tolerate pretty ones like San Anton, San Ildefonso, and others. The Mercado de Anton Martin, however, is far from being visually appealing. Since the restaurant is usually open when the market stalls are closed, it always feels like you’re sitting in some abandoned factory or warehouse with dirty floors. Besides the fact that it reeks of fish, other nasty smells also come into play and make the overall combination rather unpleasant. This obviously ruins the sushi experience (or anything else you might have ordered) and detracts from the overall enjoyment of your food. As such, I now mostly opt for takeout and enjoy the wonderful food from Yokaloka in the comfort of my own home (even if I have to wait even longer since it takes a while for me to get there).

title_review: An authentic, warm and friendly place, with great wines, meats and cheese
review_preview: We were in Madrid for two nights and staying nearby at the Artistic B&B. Casa Gonzalez was by far the friendliest place we came across, genuine warmth from the staff, who were all exceptionally polite even when very busy. We got a table after waiting...
review_full: We were in Madrid for two nights and staying nearby at the Artistic B&B.  Casa Gonzalez was by far the friendliest place we came across, genuine warmth from the staff, who were all exceptionally polite even when very busy.  We got a table after waiting for 15 minutes, but this gave us the opportunity to start sampling an excellent Rioja. Once seated, we were lucky enough to have live music a few feet away, we ordered a variety of wonderful cheeses, iberico ham and spicy chorizo, plus more of the fabulous red wine! We had such a lovely evening, and so much better than Casa Alberto the night before, which we found very disappointing. If we return to Madrid, we will 100% make sure we visit Casa Gonzalez again! Gracias!

So when you order, see it big and don't be afraid to take many things, because you won't have the courage to do it one more time later. But the atmosphere is really warm and looks typically Japanese in that strange wooden box located in the soooo-Spanish market of Lavapies. And the food is really deliciously Japanese! Fresh sea products, great rice, nice rolls, good recipes: it really was worth to wait. The prices are also reasonable (35 € for two people).

review_preview: After several weeks in Europe and eating the local food, it was time to have an Asian break- sushi! It is always a little risky as sushi can vary so much. But Yokaloka is excellent - a Japanese chef, a cute little Japanese-style restaurant in...
review_full: After several weeks in Europe and eating the local food, it was time to have an Asian break- sushi! It is always a little risky as sushi can vary so much. But Yokaloka is excellent - a Japanese chef, a cute little Japanese-style restaurant in the Mercado Anton Martin and friendly staff. There was a small wait as the sushi was freshly made, but a Kirin beer helped to fill in the time (they have free wi-fi as well). I had the house sushi 'Yokaloka' - 9 pieces for 11.3 Euro - very good value, a diverse selection, fresh, clean flavours and very tasty. Definitely worth a visit if you want a break from tapas!

This place serves, together with Kimura, the only genuine Japanese cuisine in Madrid. The rest is fake.

title_review: If you like Gordon's frozen fishsticks, get the fish croquettes!
review_preview: One of the concierge from our hotel recommended this restaurant, as it has gotten rave reviews. Anxious to try something really “Spanish” and upscale, I was impressed upon entering the restaurant and it’s beautiful interior. The raisin bread was the best part of the meal....
review_full: One of the concierge from our hotel recommended this restaurant, as it has gotten rave reviews. Anxious to try something really “Spanish” and upscale, I was impressed upon entering the restaurant and it’s beautiful interior. The raisin bread was the best part of the meal. We dressed to the nines for our first real night out on the town, but it didn’t matter. Service took a very long time. Sat down, and once the server realized we didn’t speak Spanish fluently, he gave us American menus and then would disappear like -----, Jason was so thirsty for water at one point, he actually flipped his water glass upside down, because it was dry as a bone, to maybe show a sign to a server, instead the server took it away. Haha. Different customs I guess (even though we had to pay for the water).   We ordered:   Our starter(complimentary) two pieces of sliced baguettes with squiggle piped mashed potato? Tasted like baby food that was broiled quickly by a salamander… one bite of that   Bread – not included, price is 5 EUROS per piece > the white bread was hard and I later thought I should have kept it to throw to get someones attention when we were ignored… the raisin bread was fantastic   Mineral Water 4 EUROS In actual glass unlabeled bottles, mineral water from where… maybe a filter in the back? Hmmm…   Jamon Iberico Bellota (Acorn fed Iberian cured ham) 25.50 EUROS – absolutely the best part of my meal, a huge portion, and very tasty, My reason for visiting Spain!   Croquetas Varidas (Home-made creamy croquettes, different filling every day)13.80 EUROS The ham and cheese were tasty. The ones with fish remnded me of a creamy version of Gordon’s fish sticks from the US. Mehhh. Couldn’t eat. And the third, even worse, couldn’t pinpoint that taste. The cheese shavings? More like the rind of the cheese. Hard as a rind. Inedible.   Carravalseca Copa (2 glasses @ 4 EUROS) 8 EUROS Should have just gotten drunk for dinner   Merluza A la Plancha >>bilbaina lomo 22.50 EUROS (this was to replace the inedible meat dish he ordered) His beef was SOOO overcooked and looked like it was second class airplane slop, or a Hungryman dinner. Took over 45 seconds to cut through with a knife, tasteless and chewy. Not even brown sauce to cover it. Potatoes were also bland AF. His replacement fish (after I had to call a server over and explain to him, (as a chef myself) that his dish was simply inedible and unfortunate, offered him a fish dish not on the American menu. Figures. They must think that Americans only enjoy McDonalds or something. The fish was tastier and the roasted tomato. The potatoes were basically the same.

title_review: You could eat here, but why?
review_preview: We thought this place was going to be excellent, especially since the owner greeted us with enthusiasm and since the location was so beautiful and full of locals. However, the waitstaff is a detriment to this restaurant, and the food, while good, cannot overcome such...
review_full: We thought this place was going to be excellent, especially since the owner greeted us with enthusiasm and since the location was so beautiful and full of locals. However, the waitstaff is a detriment to this restaurant, and the food, while good, cannot overcome such a painful shortcoming. The weird part is, I don't even consider myself very judgmental on that score. We've eaten all over the world -- from Michelin 3-starred restaurants to street vendors -- and I've learned to deal with both snobbery and distraction. But there was something about this place that was just so negative and strange that I have to caution you against it. If you MUST try it, order the prized fake lasagna because it is truly pillowy and delicious. The prices aren't bad, and it IS a beautiful little garden, so if you're hell-bent on eating here, that's the way to go. Otherwise, seek out a local bar, suck it up, and order a slice of jamon. We wish we had.

review_preview: I think we went on a bad day which I am taking into consideration as we had such high hopes and knew some of the people who had given it five star reviews. Sacha is not the easiest restaurant to find even with GPS as...
review_full: I think we went on a bad day which I am taking into consideration as we had such high hopes and knew some of the people who had given it five star reviews. Sacha is not the easiest restaurant to find even with GPS as it is at the rear of where it should be and is hidden away in a corner when you do find the right side of the building. On entering everything looks great, small but cosy, busy and traditional. We had two fluent Spanish speakers in our party so there was no excuse for misinterpretation or confusion but that's what happened. We asked for several starters which were mysteriously unavailable and so asked for a selection that the waiter would recommend. The result was disappointing, yes the tomato bread is good but not €15 good. The anchovies were good not salty and the tortilla with chorizo was beautifully cooked but not memorable. For the mains we ordered the Gallo which was good but not great, the solomillo which was excellent and the lamb with marrow which was very good indeed, the lasagne was extremely average. Desserts were decent but we felt rushed throughout. Everyone was happy with the wines selected by the waiter and it was noted that they didn't push us to choose expensively. Good but not great. I would try again as I'm sure it would be far better.

review_full: This is a small but great restaurant in the business district north of Bernabéu Stadium. It has the reputation of being a place where many chefs from other restaurants dine (according to my cab driver and a NYT article). The address of the restaurant is the front of the building. Sacha is located on the back of the building so you need to walk to the east end of the building and go around the corner to the back. The menu (only in Spanish)changes daily based on what is available in the market. It might be difficult if no one in the group is a Spanish speaker. My friends and I shared smoked sardines in white sauce, "false" lasagna of sea urchins, and lentil stew. My main course was butifarra sausages with grilled vegetables. My friends had small lamb chops with garlic shoots and merluza (hake) a la romana. Everything was superb. The wine selection was first rate, and the desserts were delicious. Service was impeccable as you would expect in one of the finest restaurants in Madrid.

I followed with grilled calamari, caramelised to perfection. I was unable to finish it, which was a pity!  Coffee came with 2 little squares of soft cake. Managed those!  The bill was about 50 euros, which included a glass of white wine too. Not bad if shared between two!! The waiters were attentive and friendly. There were a number of other tourists but some locals too.  This is a high end restaurant and would be suitable for a special celebration. It was also good for a solo traveller who wanted to enjoy well prepared Spanish food!!

review_preview: Really happy that we found this place, so pleased with it that we visited twice during our trip. This is a traditional Tapas bar with a VERY good selection of wines and good quality food.Before I go on I want to defend the place…....
review_full: Really happy that we found this place, so pleased with it that we visited twice during our trip.  This is a traditional Tapas bar with a VERY good selection of wines and good quality food. Before I go on I want to defend the place…. TatianaC1943….your barking mad, no normal person would sit in a bar for 2 hours and not mention that your food hadn’t arrived, did you only have one drink in that time? Even a non-drinker would have at least a glass of water after 30 minutes of waiting, were you even in the right place in the first place? Not all the food is from cans, what I do know that is from a can (because they sell it as well, in cans strangely) are snails, olives, anchovies. You say that you paid 50 Euros and only had a couple of meals? I think you had been drinking a bit more than your letting on, ensaladas are on average 12 euros, the pate is average 4 euros ! We first visited early on a Friday evening , nice and busy with a great mix of people, locals and tourists alike. We sat at one of the higher bar tables, so we could get some people watching in, also it closer to the wine rack. Fantastic range of wines and in my opinion the prices were amazing red/white from 2.50 – 3.90 euros for a glass, if you find one you really like get a bottle from the shelf, better than getting a full bottle and finding you don’t like it. We saw that there were some great cheeses and meats in the chiller as you go in, you can pick your own or just let them make one up for you, either way you won’t be disappointed. The staff were very attentive and gave some great advice on the wines and different foods. Second visit was a late Sunday afternoon (just be aware that they close about 4:30 ish) nice chatting with locals and getting more tips! The only thing we had to remind the waiters about was the fact that they had not charged us enough for our drinks! Could have got away with it but it’s a darn good place to visit and relax in!

title_review: One of the most genuine restaurant experiences ever
review_preview: The restaurant is a bit tricky to find, not exactly going out of its way to advertise itself, located down a siding, and rather than displaying the name 'SACHA', it has its full title 'Botilleria y Fogon Sacha' in non too bold lettering. Even the...
review_full: The restaurant is a bit tricky to find, not exactly going out of its way to advertise itself, located down a siding, and rather than displaying the name 'SACHA', it has its full title 'Botilleria y Fogon Sacha' in non too bold lettering. Even the local pizza delivery man wasn't too sure of the location and his shop was less than 50 meters away! We arrived about 9pm on a Monday night and were quite lucky to get a table for two, always a good sign.  I don't speak Spanish but am fairly well versed in menu Spanish, however this menu is very colloquial and doesn't really describe the ingredients in most of the dishes, so an English menu would leave English speakers none the wiser. Even Spaniards need to ask about the dishes. Luckily my friend is a native speaker so could ask about the menu. English seemed limited amongst most of the staff, however I think the sommelier was reasonably fluent, very helpful and a real delight. We started with some nice Manzanilla and salted almonds to whet the appetite, followed by a very decent Cava, Gramona, with the first two courses; Falsa Lasana, very fine pasta sheets filled with king crab and tomato, topped with sea urchin, totally divine and Pincho Rape Langostinos, rape and langoustines, simply prepared with some Romanesco sauce served on the side. Next we had a bottle of Muga Selection Especial 2011, (pre-opened, tasted and left to breath for the hour or so of our first courses) with the Villagodio Tuetano; beef (deboned cote de boeuf, I think) cooked to perfection and served with bone marrow gravy and some potato, a really great pairing.  Finally I had an amazing cheese plate with a selection of Sherries, Amontillado, Oloroso and Palo Cortado. We left the restaurant close to midnight, full and exceedingly happy, definitely a meal to remember. The bill came to about 110 euro's per person for 4 courses, Cava, Rioja, no fewer than 4 types of Sherry and a glass of Port. I am marking this mid-ranged as I have paid significantly more for a lot less; however while not quite Michelin star category quality wise I think it does qualify as fine dining. I have read some mixed reviews about this place and while I can sympathise with tourists who get taken out of their comfort zone here, I think that if you go with a versatile palate, an open mind and a willingness to communicate, you will be extremely well rewarded. Thank you Sacha

review_preview: Small bistro-like restaurant. Clients are mostly repeat business over the past 25+ years, eclectic (business mixed with artists and other interesting "fauna") kind of a reflection of the owner. The food is great - try the small fried artichokes, although anything you have will be...
review_full: Small bistro-like restaurant. Clients are mostly repeat business over the past 25+ years, eclectic (business mixed with artists and other interesting "fauna") kind of a reflection of the owner. The food is great - try the small fried artichokes, although anything you have will be tops - all the food is excellent quality as well as the wines. If you are willing to listen to him, the Head waiter will advise you well. I love this place. That said, make sure to plan ahead as it is usually fully booked, particularly in the summer months since the outdoor terrace is one of the best in Madrid and has few tables.

review_preview: By far one of the best and most imagainitve meals I have had in Madrid. We started with  home smoked sardines, followed by omlette with truffle shavings, then a bone marrow dish with steak filets as a side and to finish a super yummy chocolate...
review_full: By far one of the best and most imagainitve meals I have had in Madrid. We started with home smoked sardines, followed by omlette with truffle shavings, then a bone marrow dish with steak filets as a side and to finish a super yummy chocolate dessert. The wine pairing as chosen by the owner was perfect with the food. The owner himself is quite a character, he's very animated and pasionate about the food he cooks - his waiting staff are much more subdued. The owner does a morning radio show so it was very interesting to finally see his face after hearing his voice and he certainly lived up to his reputation.  Note that the place is very Spanish, and definitely not in the jamon and paella kind of way, so if you don't speak any Spanish, you might struggle ordering so make sure you have a dictionary app on you're phone! Otherwise, I'd definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone who is a little more adventurous with their food. Remember to book as it's always busy!

title_review: A great addition to the Grupo Oter collection
review_preview: Loved this restaurant pretty much for everything! Perfect location, great and modern space with original design, very nice selection of wines, the freshest seafood ever (and trust me we are very fastidious eaters), decent prices and very thoughtful and welcoming personnel. We have celebrated the...
review_full: Loved this restaurant pretty much for everything! Perfect location, great and modern space with original design, very nice selection of wines, the freshest seafood ever (and trust me we are very fastidious eaters), decent prices and very thoughtful and welcoming personnel. We have celebrated the birthday of our family member there and not for a second have I regretted choosing this place. The staff have offered us very personalized service: they let me bring balloons and the cake and had reserved the best table in the whole restaurant for us. More than that, they kept well all the surprises and helped to make the day even more special. Not to mention the finale when the celebratory bottle of champagne was popped for the birthday boy and was on the house. Recommend it for anyone looking for an aperitif, lunch or dinner! Their kitchen is open whole day (which is rare in Madrid). It is a truly amazing new baby of Grupo Oter which is so known for its quality. All the dishes that we tried and that were exceptional: gamba a la plancha, pulpo, lenguado, arroz con bogavante, steak tartar, ostras. Todo delicioso!

review_preview: Sacha is way outside the tourist zone, housed in a community of ugly residential towers that, to American eyes, look like housing projects at first glance. (One of the most interesting things about eating here is taking a second glance and realizing that the towers...
review_full: Sacha is way outside the tourist zone, housed in a community of ugly residential towers that, to American eyes, look like housing projects at first glance. (One of the most interesting things about eating here is taking a second glance and realizing that the towers somehow anchor a thriving upper middle class neighborhood. This is something that could never exist in the states and thus as culturally strange as the Baroque neighborhoods in Central Madrid that predate our country.) The food is uniformly good and, in summer, they basically shut the inside restaurant and serve everyone at an outdoor space between two of the towers. This outside eatery is lovely to look at but Americans who dislike summer heat may be unhappy that there's no option to eat inside. One tip on finding the place: It doesn't face onto the main street. You have to walk all the way around the building to a pedestrian courtyard to find it.

review_preview: This was by far the worst restaurant we had the misfortune to be in during our eight days in Spain. It was overcrowded, impossibly noisy and the menu was uninspiring. Our young waiter was surly and uninterested in his job. Later we had another waiter...
review_full: This was by far the worst restaurant we had the misfortune to be in during our eight days in Spain. It was overcrowded, impossibly noisy and the menu was uninspiring. Our young waiter was surly and uninterested in his job. Later we had another waiter (the one with the beard) and he was like a breath of fresh air. But unfortunately he served us just once and then we were back to Mr Surly. One of our dishes never arrived but it was listed in our bill. When I brought it to the attention of the surly guy, he looked at it, scowled, said nothing, made a new bill, never spoke a word. We were seated right up against a series of tables joined together and occupied by a guide and about 12 tourists from the U.S. The noise was incredible. The guide was doing his bit, shouting at the top of his voice information about the food and wines. Shouting to be heard, because half of the group were paying no attention to him but shouting to each other. It was like being in a bad movie. After some time the tourist group left and we had a few minutes of blessed relief before another group of estadounidenses arrived with their guide and went to the same table as their predecessors. More mayhem. Clearly this place is on a list that local guides have, of places in Madrid to bring their tourists. The place is so full that the owners don't need to concern themselves with good food or good service. We fled as soon as we could.

title_review: Difficult to locate, less than expected food
review_preview: I dined here last night with 3 friends. Never mind that the restaurant is located at the back of a small street, and it's number doesn't relate to its location, somehow the food we had didn't come up to the expectations and hype created in...
review_full: I dined here last night with 3 friends. Never mind that the restaurant is located at the back of a small street, and it's number doesn't relate to its location, somehow the food we had didn't come up to the expectations and hype created in the reviews. We had mussels, artichoke, sardines in white sauce for shared starters. So far so good. But the mains were a tad disappointing. I guess part of the problem was we didn't understand what we were ordering. The bone marrow with a side of steak was good. That dish was highly recommended in the reviews. They were out of sea urchin which is what I wanted, and was recommend cod with potatoes. It was blah. White sauce and 3 boiled potatoes. Can't say much for the rest of the mains.  Try the almond cake desert. That seems to be a winner. Many people ordered it but I didn't try it.  I guess the bar for dining in Spain is set so high that it's difficult to get approval ratings the dining experience is a let down. So sorry Sacha.

title_review: The peak of tradition - refined simplicity, wonderful food
review_preview: Not the easiest place to find, but well worth the effort. From Castellana follow Juan Hurtado de Moendoza to the end, turn left at El Olvido, Rubaiyat restaurant is next door. Turn left down the alley there and you will find the blue outside of...
review_full: Not the easiest place to find, but well worth the effort. From Castellana follow Juan Hurtado de Moendoza to the end, turn left at El Olvido, Rubaiyat restaurant is next door. Turn left down the alley there and you will find the blue outside of Sacha further along the same building. The restaurant itself simply oozes tradition, it feels like its always been there. Welcome and service is very good , everything is very nicely presented and the food is very good. The menu lists what look like simple traditional dishes- but the cooking is fabulous. Each dish focuses simply on the main ingredient with the addition of just the right amount of sauce, seasoning to make it taste at its best - simply wonderful. We tried the cress salad as a side dish. If you think cress is just something you sprinkle on top of a dish, try this and think again.

title_review: Classic and a little bit pricey. Nice garden
review_preview: We went for a dinner on a warm summer evening. The restaurant is hidden in a small street between buildings. To easily find it, look for Rubaiyat’s terrace and it is next to it. Very nice garden to eat, with trees and plenty of space...
review_full: We went for a dinner on a warm summer evening. The restaurant is hidden in a small street between buildings. To easily find it, look for Rubaiyat’s terrace and it is next to it. Very nice garden to eat, with trees and plenty of space between tables.  The food was quite good. Classic Mediterranean cooking with some innovative details. We loved the “sardinas” and the steak tartar. We ordered teh tartar lightly spiced, and it was a little more than expected, but still OK. The “raya” was quite good and fresh, but not very tasty (probably that kind of fish isn’t tasty in general). We did not order dessert and the total price was 82€ for two people (we were not so hungry, so usually it will be more than that). The service was correct, very polite, but some smiles won’t do any harm. In particular, we were surprised by the disgust face of the waitress when we told her we did not want any dessert. No big deal, anyway. Another negative point is that they only have one type of beer and it is not particularly good.

title_review: Friendly, gracious, excellent wine variety, great food
review_preview: This is day six of our trip to Madrid. This little spot has to be one of the highlights. The gentlemen running the place (could they be father and son?) were warm, friendly and very accommodating. Madrid is a big city and we've found many...
review_full: This is day six of our trip to Madrid. This little spot has to be one of the highlights.  The gentlemen running the place (could they be father and son?) were warm, friendly and very accommodating. Madrid is a big city and we've found many of the local restaurant employees to be indifferent to our presence if not simply rude. There have been a few notable exceptions and Gonzalez was a pleasant one.  We popped in for a late lunch and discovered they have an exhaustive wine selection. Probably 2 dozen wines offered by the glass. We speak very little Spanish but they were very accommodating and understanding. Both gentlemen we dealt with spoke a little English which was helpful. Our daughter joined us about a 1/2 hour later and we were never rushed at all.  The food was great too.

review_preview: This was one of our favourite spots during our recent visit to Madrid.  We came upon it initially by chance and ended up visiting three times.  It is a combination delicatessen/wine bar, with a wonderful selection of cured meats and cheeses and a large superb...
review_full: This was one of our favourite spots during our recent visit to Madrid. We came upon it initially by chance and ended up visiting three times. It is a combination delicatessen/wine bar, with a wonderful selection of cured meats and cheeses and a large superb selection of wines by the glass. We had several dishes here and enjoyed them all, particularly the cheese plate. We let the staff select the cheeses and the variety and flavours were first rate, all interesting Spanish cheeses. We tried a number of wines and were very impressed by the wide range of good Spanish wines, particularly the reds. They also sell a large selection of wines by the bottle, and we bought four to bring home. We will definitely return to Gonzalez on our next trip to Madrid.

title_review: The best place for cheese, salumi, and wine
review_preview: First, I stepped inside quite accidentally, I just liked their display of cheeses. The place was busy, there were no free tables, just one seat at the desk. What made me stay, was their extensive selection of wines per glass. Actually, most of the usual...
review_full: First, I stepped inside quite accidentally, I just liked their display of cheeses. The place was busy, there were no free tables, just one seat at the desk. What made me stay, was their extensive selection of wines per glass.  Actually, most of the usual tourist places in Madrid have 30-40 different wines per bottle, but when travelling alone, and for work, I normally do not need a whole bottle of wine for lunch, all for myself. I would much prefer to taste one or two glasses of LOCAL wine, rather than standard industrial trash. But these places only keep 3-4 open bottles, always EXACTLY the same, Rioja, Ribera, whatever, BORING.  This place was different, I started TALKING to the owner and bartenders (for me, as an Italophone, that was easy), and followed their advice. If you are a tourist, they may be disposed to treat you as a tourist. But when they recognise you are a traveller, they reciprocate. And they may suggest you GREAT wines, GREAT cheeses, and simple, local, tasty food. In this place, and a similar bottega in Granada (La Brujidera), in a few days I've discovered more local flavours, than in preceding years. The quality/price ratio is AMAZINGLY high. You pay 2 euro for a glass of wine, of the same stature as the one for which you pay 5-6 euro in Siena, and a complete meal is 12-15 euro.

review_preview: I ended up in Gonzalez by pure serendipity, and it was a fantastic experience. It's a tapas bar disguised as a delicatessen / wine store founded in 1931. They take the products they sell (great cheese, cold cuts, foie gras, etc) and sell them in...
review_full: I ended up in Gonzalez by pure serendipity, and it was a fantastic experience. It's a tapas bar disguised as a delicatessen / wine store founded in 1931. They take the products they sell (great cheese, cold cuts, foie gras, etc) and sell them in a tiny, enchanting set of tables and a bar at the back of the place. Every single product is fresh, delicious. You can order at least 20 different wines by the glass, and the bottles are quite fairly priced as well. And they offer toasts of every single thing they have in store. Beware: no salads, no meats, no fish. Only toasts with a huge variety of cheese, cold cuts and stuff like that on top. Simple, but amazingly tasty, and the atmosphere is always fun. To make things even better, the service is knowledgeable and really enjoy their job. I'll be back.

review_full: We wanted to taste wines and found this little shop (room in the back in case it looks busy). Having eaten a proper meal around noonish, the group wondered in at 1315, right before the rush.  Everything we tried was good, if not great. The Moscato was sweet, but everyone enjoyed it with toast and cheese. Personal favorite: La From, a full red, not to dry, perfect for any time. Try their toasts with cheese, or if with a few people, a cheese sampler. Order wine with cheese or cheese with wine, the staff (no matter how young) are well prepared to guide you through.

Be sure to check out the specials which are created from whatever seems fresh at the market. Solid in every way.

review_preview: Great restaurant! We heard they had excellent paella, and we were not disappointed. The host and the waitress were extremely attentive and welcoming - the waitress did not speak English, but we communicated well enough nevertheless. Food was extremely good. Three of us shared two...
review_full: Great restaurant! We heard they had excellent paella, and we were not disappointed. The host and the waitress were extremely attentive and welcoming - the waitress did not speak English, but we communicated well enough nevertheless. Food was extremely good. Three of us shared two appetizers - a tuna tartare with avocado, perhaps the best tuna tartare I've ever had, and "the specialty of the house" (unknowned to us when we ordered it), a lightly fried artichoke dish that was out of this world (and VERY plentiful - four artichokes, a meal by itself). We then shared the house special seafood paella - really wonderful, the best we've had in a long time and the best thus far in 5 days in Spain. For dessert, again "the house special", a french toast brioche, very delicious. We left overstuffed but very happy!

title_review: You are in spain, eat spanish
review_preview: We asked the receptionist at our Hotel to recommend a Tapas Bar for lunch, and he gave us instructions as to where to find it.  Well worth the effort, by pass all the franchises, chains and multiples and you find yourself at a shopfront that...
review_full: We asked the receptionist at our Hotel to recommend a Tapas Bar for lunch, and he gave us instructions as to where to find it. Well worth the effort, by pass all the franchises, chains and multiples and you find yourself at a shopfront that does not stand out as a restaurant. We squeezed in and were led out to the rear dining room, we were only 2 people but made a selection of well priced tapas that were all tasty and wholesome, accompanied by a wonderful bottle of Rueda Verdejo. The place had a great buzz about, as all the other clients were spanish. A GREAT back street discovery and so far removed from the usual touristic overpriced gin palaces. Come and taste spain.

review_preview: We went twice to this restaurant while we were in Madrid.  We went on the 1st night and also 2 days before leaving Madrid since we had tickets for a show at El Teatro de la Zarzuela which is only 5 minutes walk away, and...
review_full: We went twice to this restaurant while we were in Madrid. We went on the 1st night and also 2 days before leaving Madrid since we had tickets for a show at El Teatro de la Zarzuela which is only 5 minutes walk away, and because it’s one of the few restaurants that is opened early in Madrid. The food and service were very good on both occasions but my favorite dish had to be the Rabo de Toro which is oxtail. It was so tender with the right amount of spices. Their chocolate soufflé is also worth mentioning as we ordered it both times we were there. It’s a beautiful restaurant that serves delicious food and I totally recommend it for any occasion.

title_review: Relaxing evening with good food and excellent service
review_preview: El Barril de las Cortes is an up-market seafood restaurant located in the Las Cortes district of Madrid between the Gran Via and the metro stop Sevilla.  It was the perfect place to spend a leisurely evening with a luscious Albariño wine and a copious...
review_full: El Barril de las Cortes is an up-market seafood restaurant located in the Las Cortes district of Madrid between the Gran Via and the metro stop Sevilla. It was the perfect place to spend a leisurely evening with a luscious Albariño wine and a copious menu to choose from, including special tasting menus which a group of young international professionals at the nearby table were experiencing.  The wait staff was particularly exceptional in not hovering over and asking if all was ok. They know when guests are enjoying the atmosphere and food and do not want to be bothered with interruptions. They also know when it is appropriate to approach a table. For us, a hefty plate of pimientos de padrón (small green peppers with the occasional hot one) was followed by the ubiquitous paella which we seemed to be in the mood for, in spite of all the many items on the menu that also got our attention and we wanted to try, but will save for another time. The abundance of food, all rich and flavorful was too much to eat, but dessert was not to be missed. A fruit creation comprised of blackberries, raspberries, kiwis, mangoes and currants graced the plate, surrounding a “flower cup” made of thinly sliced pineapple “leaves” with blueberries and orange sherbet topped with fresh mint leaves. It was the perfect choice to follow the rich and hearty paella before finishing with a soothing and definitive expresso. Can’t wait to return!

Later in the meal a courteous young man waited the table, and did so very well. There was nothing to fault in the two fish dishes we enjoyed. The starters were excellent as well. The atmosphere was busy and energetic, while retaining a slightly quieter atmosphere for comfortable dining. This is a thriving restaurant.

review_preview: On our first night in Madrid, we are at this small restaurant recommended by our hotel, Hotel Villa Real. What a blast!  The owner and staff warmed up to us after my feeble attempts to speak Spanish, but we were understood more than enough!  Of...
review_full: On our first night in Madrid, we are at this small restaurant recommended by our hotel, Hotel Villa Real. What a blast! The owner and staff warmed up to us after my feeble attempts to speak Spanish, but we were understood more than enough! Of course, the meal starts with complementary olives, bread and pate. My wife had onion soup to start. Quite different than the French onion soup we eat in the States, a bit creamier, but nice. I had the 6 type salad, which included oranges, apples and greens. For main courses, we had a seafood mix in broth and grilled calamari, which was excellent. The Spanish white and red wines by the glass were very good. We were so full we couldn't order desert, but they brought us small tastes on the house and then shots of a sweet after dinner drunk. We were chatting with some other Americans at the next table (from Miami who spoke Spanish), sharing stories and tucking it up with the owners and waitstaff. Good food and a great atmosphere.

review_preview: I give this low rating for the service, the food for today would be 3stars maximum. So, we were the first guests for dinner. We came at 7pm, made a reservation after enjoying lunch at this place yesterday. Thank you, Xavier for not forgetting to...
review_full: I give this low rating for the service, the food for today would be 3stars maximum. So, we were the first guests for dinner. We came at 7pm, made a reservation after enjoying lunch at this place yesterday. Thank you, Xavier for not forgetting to mention in the reservation, that it was my birthday tonight ( we learnt, that the stuff was aware of it after 9pm). Our waitress, ( who didn’t speak a word of English) served us t two cold white buns, I asked to replace with warm and fresh and rye ( we tasted them at lunch) and she reluctantly did. Beware! They charge you for bread( as in many Spanish restaurants). Then she brought my husband steamed ( not fried) clams. The octopus( which we loved at lunch) was barely warm and mashed potatoes were literally floating in oil.. And still we managed to stay in good mood. We ordered dessert around 8.20, we asked the waitress twice- she was answering in Spanish, finally at 9 we cancelled coffee and dessert and this is when another waiter ( male ) appeared with this dessert with a candle for me! Telling me- I am sorry and no charge for dessert! Does he think, that out festive mood is worth a couple of euros and nearly an hour wait?! Bottom line- very poorly and unprofessionally organized service in the evening and food awaits too long to be served. And lastly- we are staying in Hotel Villa Real for about 10 days and visited practically all local restaurants. It was hard to choose one for my birthday. It was a definitely a wrong choice. Wouldn’t recommend for dinner or any kind of celebration.

title_review: Nice dinner in a warm place.
review_preview: Due to an overbooking in another restaurant, we had to reserve at 10:00 PM a table for 4 people in real time. We got the table and have been nicely accommodated. Service excellent, good list of wine, very broad menu. We were immediately offered olives...
review_full: Due to an overbooking in another restaurant, we had to reserve at 10:00 PM a table for 4 people in real time. We got the table and have been nicely accommodated. Service excellent, good list of wine, very broad menu. We were immediately offered olives and a delicious mise en bouche with octopus and vegetable misiticanza. Appetizers were very good (galliega octopus and cod omelette), as well as the two types of paella (lobster+monk fish and jumbo shrimps+clams). The white wine was an excellent Spanish Sauvignon. The dishes were generous. So, no room for dessert.

review_preview: Disappointing evening at this restaurant. There’s no dedicated waiter for each table, just whoever is passing by attends to you, and we seemed to have been completely forgotten for most of the night. We’d bought a bottle of wine and they only did small pours,...
review_full: Disappointing evening at this restaurant. There’s no dedicated waiter for each table, just whoever is passing by attends to you, and we seemed to have been completely forgotten for most of the night. We’d bought a bottle of wine and they only did small pours, so we were constantly waiting for refills of wine as well as water. The female waitress seemed very unfriendly, she didn’t seem happy to be waiting on tourists even though we’d dressed up and intended to have a lovely evening. It was also not particularly busy when we got there at 8:30pm so service should have been much better.  We ordered the jamon salad with sun dried tomatoes which was lovely. We then shared the chicken and beef paella which was mostly lovely, though the beef was very over cooked and we left some in the pan. Rice and chicken were lovely.  Overall just disappointing. Style over substance.

title_review: Delightful meal with fresh and genuine flavours on all seafood dishes!
review_preview: As recommended by the concierge, this place indeed did not disappoint. Opt for an early dinner and stay within dining area instead of tapas bar at the front, both areas are great with dining area having a fine dining decor. Service is helpful, with no...
review_full: As recommended by the concierge, this place indeed did not disappoint. Opt for an early dinner and stay within dining area instead of tapas bar at the front, both areas are great with dining area having a fine dining decor. Service is helpful, with no problem conversing in English from one of the waitress while the other not as fluent but made up for her eagerness to serve us well! Food is immaculate, house white wine is slight sweet, fragrant and matched well with the baked freshly caught seabass in salt crust, serving for two but good enough for three, meat is soft, tender and melts in your mouth! Grilled red prawns are soft, tender but oh so sweet in favour which is contrary to the usual textural style of ones we used to have. Even the shrimp head cream is also so sweet . The octopus is well prepared as well, with such tender chewiness, gotta try it to believe, another standout! Price is on pricey side but well worth it for the whole experience! Forgot to mention is the complimentary soup made of pumpkin and other veggies which is soooo sweet and delicious. Alright , I had used "sweet" many times...lol

Beware of the "closing hours"-they close around five and reopen at eight, after being open from one to five, so you do not go there for an early "american time" meal! One of the servers (David, or Daveed) is especially friendly. This is a local place that feels very welcoming for visitors. It can get crowded but that is part of the charm of the place.

review_preview: Fully packed and with just a few stools, this hectic taberna serves very tasty Spanish fare in one of Madrid's upscale neighborhoods. Great fish and seafood, good jamón and tapas. Full of locals, off the beaten path. Not sure anyone in the staff will speak...
review_full: Fully packed and with just a few stools, this hectic taberna serves very tasty Spanish fare in one of Madrid's upscale neighborhoods.  Great fish and seafood, good jamón and tapas. Full of locals, off the beaten path. Not sure anyone in the staff will speak English though, but they're efficient and outgoing, so that shouldn't be an issue. I always wonder why foreign visitors to Spain aren't a little more adventurous and go where the locals go. This place is a worthwhile first step in that direction. You can't go wrong here. Was my first visit, won't be my last.  Expect however a fully packed place, with little personal space.

review_preview: I agree with other reviewers - this place has the best tapas in Madrid. Dishes were flavorful, clean, and high quality. The tapas portions were so large, I thought we accidentally ordered full portions!After having a mediocre meal at the popular Taberna del Chato,...
review_full: I agree with other reviewers - this place has the best tapas in Madrid. Dishes were flavorful, clean, and high quality. The tapas portions were so large, I thought we accidentally ordered full portions! After having a mediocre meal at the popular Taberna del Chato, I didn't expect much at Emma's. But I was really impressed with almost everything.  The gazpacho was amazing! A must order. 5/5 The hamburger with caramelized onions was also delicious. 5/5 The morcilla in a pastry puff was also good. The bed of sautéed peppers was the star though. 4/5 The tagine of lamb was authentic, flavorful, and delicious. 5/5 The potatoes look simple but the 2 sauces are amazing! 5/5 The oxtail wasn't great but not bad either. It's a little heavy and lacking something. 2/5 The tuna tasted way too fishy. Wouldn't recommend. 1/5 I wish I found Emma before our last night in Madrid, but we did get to try many dishes (more than we could finish)! 7 dishes and 2 drinks only 34 euros!!!

title_review: Tiny but big on quality, value and friendliness.
review_preview: We (a group of 7 and a group of 6)  ate at Emma's twice during our recent week in Madrid and were very happy on each occasion, the second visit being the superior one since we were not relegated to the back room. The restaurant...
review_full: We (a group of 7 and a group of 6) ate at Emma's twice during our recent week in Madrid and were very happy on each occasion, the second visit being the superior one since we were not relegated to the back room. The restaurant is very small, and the atmosphere understated but our waitress on both occasions, Vanessa, was able to keep everyone happy. We had tapas both nights, throwing some specials into the mix but the veal kofta ( well-seasoned meatballs served with warm, soft pita and two sauces - pepper and tzatziki), and the lamb tajine were highlights. The house wine was excellent and very reasonable as were our bills for outstanding food. Kudos to Vanessa and to Emma!

review_full: Was busy and full when we first arrived as there is limited seating. We weren't sure if we should wait a little for a table or not, but ended up waiting; and glad we did! Service was great! The lone server was attentive, timely and efficient but laid back and friendly as well. Menus in English provided.Server spoke several languages as far as we could tell. Music was at a perfect level to facilitate conversation but not so low that you could hear conversation at the tables that were quite close beside us. We shared the amazing Smoked Salmon and avocado Tapa on bread and a delicious Jamón Pizza with arugula along with 4 glasses of red wine between the two of us. Came to a reasonable price of 28€ for it all and we had left over too. Would highly recommend this place to anyone wanting a meal from a simple but delicious menu! Wanted to try the empanadas and salads but we're too full. Try this place !

review_preview: We came across this place as we were looking for a place to have a late lunch. What a wonderful surprise. The staples of any rodízio are the rice, the beans and the meat. All three were superb. I’m used to rodízios but this place...
review_full: We came across this place as we were looking for a place to have a late lunch. What a wonderful surprise. The staples of any rodízio are the rice, the beans and the meat. All three were superb. I’m used to rodízios but this place really stands out for quality. The tastiest black beans I’ve had in recent times. And the meat was plenty, it was juicy and I liked the fact that they will ensure you get the cuts you want rather than try to stuff you with less popular cuts - a tactic employed by many restaurants that follow the “Rodízio” model. The only thing one could point out is that the rest of the buffet isn’t particularly varied vis-à-vis other similar restaurants. I for one value quality over quantity (and variety) so this didn’t bother me at all. The salads were there, the rice, beans, farofa, couve mineira and grilled vegetables were all there so we had more than enough to keep us busy through the 2 hours we’ve yyyspent there savouring their wonderful food.

review_full: Having spend a week in Spain eating nothing but Spanish cuisine, i feel rather confident in saying that Taberna Cazorla offers the best Spanish cuisine out there! The service is very prompt and professional and menus are offered in English as well as Spanish which is always a delight in any restaurant :) We ordered several items and shared them. None of the items were anything short of amazing. Special mention goes to the seafood soup, which can be easily split between two people. The grilled octopus with potatoes is probably the best i have had during the course of the week. Overall a highly recommended restaurant if you are seeking delicious Spanish food!

review_preview: This is my favorite bar in Madrid. Years ago it was very Andulucian with canaries in cages and pictures of bullfighting. Then it changed management and became a hotspot. Why? The quality of the Tapas is excellent and so too in the restaurant. The portions...
review_full: This is my favorite bar in Madrid. Years ago it was very Andulucian with canaries in cages and pictures of bullfighting. Then it changed management and became a hotspot. Why? The quality of the Tapas is excellent and so too in the restaurant. The portions are excellent and very good value. All products are fresh. They are on display on the counter, fresh mushrooms, sardines, tomato etc. The tomato salad is the best in Spain personally.  It has a good selection of wines. If ordering red wine remember to ask for a crianza. There is also a good selection of sherries.  What I like about this place is that you go in for a small beer and see something on the counter like razor clams and end up staying there hours going through all the tapas. The bar is across the road from a retirement home and can get full of families visiting on a Sunday. See you there.

This place is busy, but there is a back room where people can sit and enjoy. A great place to catch local flavor.

title_review: Delicious cheeses, ham and other charcuteries plus great wine in a charming setting
review_preview: Gonzalez came recommended by a local and it could not have been a better recommendation. The menu includes a plethora of amazing and delicious Spanish delicacies such as jamon iberico, lomo, different cheeses, red peppers and pimientos del padron - accompanied by an excellent wine...
review_full: Gonzalez came recommended by a local and it could not have been a better recommendation. The menu includes a plethora of amazing and delicious Spanish delicacies such as jamon iberico, lomo, different cheeses, red peppers and pimientos del padron - accompanied by an excellent wine list.  Our waiter was very friendly and attentive. We sat at a high table in the front of the locale, and enjoyed a wonderful and delicious dinner for a very reasonable price. I will definitely be back! I've already recommended Gonzalez to several friends - if you're looking for authentic Spanish food in a casual setting, this is a great choice!

title_review: Amazing good, very busy and very fun.
review_preview: We stumbled across this place by pure accident. It was late afternoon, so it was closed.Given it looked quite interesting and was close to where we where staying the choice was made to come back for dinner.So very glad we did. Twice actually....
review_full: We stumbled across this place by pure accident. It was late afternoon, so it was closed. Given it looked quite interesting and was close to where we where staying the choice was made to come back for dinner. So very glad we did. Twice actually.  Keep in mind this place gets very busy with locals. Lots of wine, lots of talking. This is a little noisy place at times but a lot of fun. You do not at all feel like you stepped into a tourist trap!  Service both times was good, very helpful staff. They are very busy as well so expect a little bit of a wait as they get around to your requests. It is not bad, just busy.  The menu here is quite large not that we tried everything but all the dishes we had where very good.  Here is what we had over the two times we went for dinner: * Snails in sauce * Pigs cheek in sauce * Roasted piquillo red peppers with pine nuts * A plate of Spanish sausage * A plat of mixed cheese (5 types) (got the waiter to pick) * Gazpacho * A plate of Jamon ham Each time we went we got Jamon ham and some mixed cheeses. This place has so many Spanish cheeses that you can try. The waiter asked for our taste preference for the cheese to go into the mixed selection. We let him pick I was happy to try new cheeses.  One of the cheese plates also came with a fruit paste.  Over all the cheeses where quite nice I lost track of what each one was. The Jamon ham was also very good and quite a decent serve. Goes well with the fresh bread they have! The snail dish was quite good. Very nice taste, it seems to be based off tomato and stewed for a long time. Some bread dipped into the sauce also went down very well.  The snails where well cleaned and had very nice fresh taste. The pigs cheek we had was amazingly tender and had such a nice flavor. I am unsure of what the sauce was, I’ve not had something like it before. It however matched the pig cheek very well. The roasted piquillo red peppers with pine nuts was an interesting salad. It was dressed with a thicker vinaigrette which was a little sweet but not over the top by any means the vinegar’s amazing taste still came though.  The peppers where nicely roasted. Retaining the sweetness of the pepper.  This was well offset by the crisp taste of the salad leaves. Loved the dressing on this salad. A plate of Spanish sausages was also good, not much to say about this really. It is good sausage. I’d like to try some of the different sausages next time.  The Gazpacho also went down well. Nice flavors rich tomato taste. Though nothing amazing compared to a few others I have had else where in Spain.  Each time we asked the waiter to pick us some red wine. He selected some good ones, let us taste first. We ended up buying an extra bottle to take home with us one night. If I am back in Madrid, I will be back into this place to try more of the menu.

title_review: Don't go anywhere else for cheese and charcuterie!!
review_preview: Had a fantastic leisurely late lunch of a selection of 5 Spanish cheeses and Jamón Iberico Bellota. The quality of both were fantastic, the cheese a great selection of soft, semi-hard and hard cheeses made of different milks and all very different. You can also...
review_full: Had a fantastic leisurely late lunch of a selection of 5 Spanish cheeses and Jamón Iberico Bellota. The quality of both were fantastic, the cheese a great selection of soft, semi-hard and hard cheeses made of different milks and all very different. You can also order the cheeses one by one off the menu and make your own selection.  The ham was incredible - sweet with a deep meaty flavour and a supple, melt in the mouth texture. It was presented beautifully and the slices were paper thin.  Casa Gonzáles also has an extensive wine list to go with the food.  It's an authentic place, not at all touristy, with attentive and knowledgable service and it's very reasonably priced considering the quality of the food. If you want to try the best charcuterie and cheeses Madrid has to offer, this is the place!

title_review: Best tapas experience in the city

You can sit at a single table in the window, or on high stools in the corridor section of the establishment or more regular tables in the back room: either way, you won't be ignored. Prices were very reasonable and portions generous. A half racion of Manchego came as eight good slices. The tostadas were fab - we had smoked tuna, and melted Galician cheese with membrillo. Good place for salads, too, which is more unusual in Madrid. They will recommend wines if you wish. We liked the place so much we ate there three times in a week!

review_preview: Casa Gonzalez lives up to its highly recommended status by providing an authentic and unpretentious array of typical and truly delicious Spanish tapas and a few unique twists. Within 30 min of our concierge calling ahead on a busy Friday evening were seated at reserved...
review_full: Casa Gonzalez lives up to its highly recommended status by providing an authentic and unpretentious array of typical and truly delicious Spanish tapas and a few unique twists. Within 30 min of our concierge calling ahead on a busy Friday evening were seated at reserved table in the window and then served within seconds. Our selections (Goat cheese and anchovy salad on a bed of rocket, warm tuna salad with peppers, minced cod, a selection of 5 local cheeses) was perfectly complimented by an affordable sampling of Rioja reds. Each dish was presented with evident pride and a flourish. Other than a modest delay for the check (....patience is a traveler's most important virtue) it was a quite memorable and gastronomically memorable Madrid experience. Evidently as the restaurant became more crowded with several customers at the bar, it's worth getting here earlier in the evening.
