title_review: Great wines, good local food, very friendly staff.
review_preview: From the street this looks like a nice delicatessen selling hams, sausages, chorizos and cheeses. There are a couple of tables in the window and a couple of "gueridons" with high stools alongside the counter. The walls are covered in shelves bearing countless bottles of...
review_full: From the street this looks like a nice delicatessen selling hams, sausages, chorizos and cheeses. There are a couple of tables in the window and a couple of "gueridons" with high stools alongside the counter. The walls are covered in shelves bearing countless bottles of different Spanish wines. Further back there is a small bar and behind that more tables. The waiters, dressed in black and white, look very smart and professional. Several sported handsome black beards. We visited twice; the first time in the evening for supper and the second time for a late Sunday lunch. There were lots of customers, especially in the evening, but on both occasions the waiters found us somewhere to sit. Glasses of wine,(125 mls), poured at the table, cost between about E2,50 and E4.00. There is a huge choice. Food includes tostas (basically open toasted sandwiches), plates of meats and cheeses, and a variety of hot dishes, e.g. piquillo peppers stuffed with cod and prawns served in a rich tomato sauce. The atmosphere is lively and convivial. Although this tapas bar is clearly popular with locals we did not feel out of place and felt very welcome, especially when we visited for the second time and probably looked familiar. We shall certainly go here again next time we are in Madrid.

review_preview: My wife and I wanted to find a lovely restaurant with friends and take in a bit of the local culture. This place was recommended to our friends by a local person who was a friend of one of their children. It is located in...
review_full: My wife and I wanted to find a lovely restaurant with friends and take in a bit of the local culture. This place was recommended to our friends by a local person who was a friend of one of their children. It is located in central Madrid. We made reservations ahead of time but we really didn't have to at the time we requested. Spanish people eat at much later times than Americans. Our reservation was for 7:00 PM. We were the first people there.  We had requested a certain table which we got and the owner was very accommodating. We do speak some Spanish but they do have servers who speak basic English. Language was not an issue. As for the menu, the wine and the ambience, everything was truly outstanding. Our food was excellent and the service was great. I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone visiting Madrid. We will love it!

title_review: A Gem of a Restaurant in the Middle of Madrid: PERCEBES!
review_preview: By chance, after looking at the menu on the window, I asked the manager, "do you know where I can get some Percebes ( Wild Goose Barnacles)?" He replied, "here" They where not in the menu, but he told me they had another restaurant near...
review_full: By chance, after looking at the menu on the window, I asked the manager, "do you know where I can get some Percebes ( Wild Goose Barnacles)?" He replied, "here" They where not in the menu, but he told me they had another restaurant near and a taxi will bring them right away. Now, that is great service! I was ecstatic. We got in and had a feast that night. We had the Galician Percebes, my son never have had percebes and now is an addict. Then, the Pulpo Gallego (Galician octopus) and Grilled Octopus, both deliciosos! As an appetizer, pimientos de Padron. For dessert, hojaldre de manzana (Spanish strudel), and to top it all, Creppes Souzette al Grand Marnier (flambé next to our table). If money can not buy happiness, explain jamon serrano (prosciutto)? or El Barril de las Cortes? GRACIAS! VOLVEREMOS!

Michelin recognition disappeared 2 years ago based upon the door signs too. Very poor and we will not return.

title_review: Fantastico!! A must visit for Pizza!
review_preview: This small local restaurant on a quiet street, is Madrid's best kept secret for fantastic pizza and Italian fare. Piccolo was buzzing on this Saturday night, but the service by Fabio and Geraldine was efficient, kind and with big smiles. I dined twice, one evening...
review_full: This small local restaurant on a quiet street, is Madrid's best kept secret for fantastic pizza and Italian fare. Piccolo was buzzing on this Saturday night, but the service by Fabio and Geraldine was efficient, kind and with big smiles. I dined twice, one evening for the special Carbonara, and a second visit for the fabulous jamon y funghi pizza. Both dishes rival anything you would find in Rome to New York. The price is right, the service is great, and the food is fabulous! Stop by and say hello when in Madrid. Its a short 8 min walk from the Westin Palace.

title_review: Sad that they are so shallow and closed minded
review_preview: My family and I visited this bar to get authentic sherry as we spent two years in Andalucía enjoying their amazing sherry. There were people from Andalucía in the bar who were enjoying themselves and, in true Andalucía fashion, began to clap and sing their...
review_full: My family and I visited this bar to get authentic sherry as we spent two years in Andalucía enjoying their amazing sherry. There were people from Andalucía in the bar who were enjoying themselves and, in true Andalucía fashion, began to clap and sing their bulerías and Sevillanas. The bar is adorned with feria posters and posters of Jerez, the birthplace of flamenco. The owner quickly came over, told them to stop and threatened to call the police if they didn’t stop singing. Such clearly shallow and racist behavior is just divisive and puts a dark smudge on this place for me. We left in protest, wishing we could have enjoyed our oloroso with authentic music and jubilation from the native crowd. I don’t think we’ll be back. I don’t support that sort of closed-mindedness, especially when they are making their money from an Andalusian product with posters of the region all over the bar. Shame on La Venecia.

title_review: A barrio wine bar with lots of atmosphere!
review_preview: La Venencia is a barrio wine bar, reeking of atmosphere, character and antique-ness, specializing in sherries and amontillados. But I always take away enjoyment points if that character and atmosphere gets self-righteous and snooty to the extent of forbidding the taking of photos. A rather...
review_full: La Venencia is a barrio wine bar, reeking of atmosphere, character and antique-ness, specializing in sherries and amontillados. But I always take away enjoyment points if that character and atmosphere gets self-righteous and snooty to the extent of forbidding the taking of photos. A rather grumpy bartender didn't win any service points from me either when he failed to thank me for returning incorrect change to him that, had I kept it, would have resulted in La Venencia paying me to stand there and drink! Enjoyable and recommended as a "been there, done that" quirky Madrid hole-in-the-wall.

title_review: This is a place where locals eat
review_preview: The cuisine is more Italian than Spanish but the food is exquisitely prepared, the service very professional and the dining room quiet. It is only a few blocks north from the Ribiero and one block south of the Archiological museum. The bathroom foyer was well...
review_full: The cuisine is more Italian than Spanish but the food is exquisitely prepared, the service very professional and the dining room quiet. It is only a few blocks north from the Ribiero and one block south of the Archiological museum. The bathroom foyer was well worth a photo! The pizza was beautifully prepared, the salad was lovely and the pasta with clams was gorgeously garlicky. But our favorite was the olives which had been seasoned with something that made them red in color, hot paprika perhaps. Lastly the cappuccinos were made Italian style, with only a hint of chocolate on top unlike the Spanish style which have quite a bit of chocolate added to them. The hostest, a native of Romania, was fantastic and is gifted in languages, speaking Spanish, English and her native language fluently, Italian and French conversationally and is in the process of learning German.  Highly recommend this restaurant.

The team prides itself on being dining experts having worked in some the finest restaurants in Spain and even a 2 Michelin Star restaurant.  What a huge disappointment despite their experience and being in a prime location. In a well heeled neighborhood, with lots of competition, you would expect good service, quality and atmosphere.  On all three, they scored 0.  Chilly reception coupled with poor service at the bar. It seemed we were more an inconvenience than potential repeat customer. If they continue treating its customers like this, just like it’s predecessors, I don’t expect Santerra lasting much longer.  The deathly atmosphere and atrocious service was enough for us to walk our after a few minutes. I couldn’t finish my beverage quick enough. Didn’t want to waste more time and money. I’m happy to spend it elsewhere but there.

title_review: Good place - nothing more, nothing less
review_preview: Started with a pre-dinner cocktail that looked and tasted amazing. The staff were friendly and guided us through the menu. At a start the have us a menu in English, but when we were ready to order they told us the menu was dated and...
review_full: Started with a pre-dinner cocktail that looked and tasted amazing. The staff were friendly and guided us through the menu. At a start the have us a menu in English, but when we were ready to order they told us the menu was dated and gave us the new menu in Spanish. Unfortunately were there several of the dishes we wanted to order no longer on the menu. I was quite disappointed.  The food was good and we liked it. But, I think they easily could have stepped up a level. For instance did we get exactly the same sauces to the empanada and the triradito. Which is quite strange since the empanada is meat, while the tiradito is raw fish marinated in citrus. We also had a few nigiri, with delicious tuna belly. The rice did however not meet the standard. Understand me correct: it was good, but we expected more from this place.  We shared 7 dishes and order a bottle of wine, two cocktails and two coffee for just above 110 Euro. I think it is good value for the money A good measurement for a restaurant is how likely it is that I would recommend this to friends. I think I wouldn’t mention Chow Chow if some one asks me about restaurants in Madrid. In case someone asked me about it, I would say it is a nice place with good food. And I would definitely not discourage any one from going.

title_review: A must visit for sherry + ambiance
review_preview: A great small bar not far from the Prado, the draw here is beautiful sherry drawn from casks and served in unmarked bottles. Simple snacks are available - do not miss the salty chess with the sherry! And that’s it - different lovely sherries, from...
review_full: A great small bar not far from the Prado, the draw here is beautiful sherry drawn from casks and served in unmarked bottles. Simple snacks are available - do not miss the salty chess with the sherry!  And that’s it - different lovely sherries, from light manzanilla on up to heavier oloroso, plus simple snacks. Perfect for pre- or post-lunch or -dinner.  A bar with at least 90 years of history - a time capsule still similar to what Hemingway would have experienced when he helped plot revolution back in the day. (And the “no photos!” rule on the wall from then still applies, so be warned not to take that irresistible selfie in here.)  Do read up online on the story of what a venencia actually is, and how it is used in sherry making and tasting: there’s one on the wall behind the bar!  This place is a treat!

review_full: After randomly visiting here on a recent trip to Madrid, i have to say I now absolutely love this place!!! The food was fantastic!!! The buffet selection was great with various salads, rice and other dishes available to satisfy all tastes but it was the meat selection that was the King here. A wonderful variety on offer all expertly cooked to perfection!!! The Juicy succulent cuts available left us completely full and thoroughly satisfied!!!! Drinks were recommended by Rui (Caipirinhas!) and were absolutely spot on. Perfect on a blazing hot day, as it was on that day. We went for a "spot of lunch" and ended up not wanting to leave, staying there for a good few hours enjoying the never ending supply of great food on offer. The staff working there were extremely helpful and friendly and Rui and Joao were fantastic hosts. Even during a very busy lunch, they made us feel comfortable and at home and that nothing was too much trouble. It was without doubt, one of the best places we ate in Madrid, I would highly recommend a visit to Vila Brasil. Keep up the good work and Well done guys!!! Awesome!!

So forget Tapas for a night, leave your hotel of villa and let the boys at Vila Brasilia fill your plate, for less than 20 Euros you will feast like a king. Keep up the great work guys, you deserve every success. Kind regards Jason

review_preview: We visited this amazing steakhouse on our recent trip to Madrid.The meat was so delicious and succulent with an amazing variety of choices. The hot buffet also had a large choice of dishes to choice from and was equally as impressive as the meat choice....
review_full: We visited this amazing steakhouse on our recent trip to Madrid.The meat was so delicious and succulent with an amazing variety of choices.  The hot buffet also had a large choice of dishes to choice from and was equally as impressive as the meat choice.  The extensive drinks menu left us struggling as to what to order but with expert advice from one of the friendly owners the decision was made and the most delightful Strawberry Caipirinha was served up and tasted amazing.  We enjoyed the whole experience of this new modern yet authentic steakhouse so much that we returned for a second visit a couple of days later,shortly before our brief 5 day visit came to an end. We can't wait to return to Madrid to once again enjoy this magical dining experience. Many thanks to Rui (owner) and all the staff who made our visit so very memorable. Keep up the good work guys!

review_full: I like to recognize people who I feel are extra special-those who take great pride in what they do and genuinely care about the people they deal with. Dairo, the manager of “Flavia,” is one such individual. When we arrived at his restaurant for dinner, upon hearing that my husband had allergies (nuts & fish), he introduced himself, presented us with several alternative menus and spent considerable time discussing different options for my husband, all the time patient and with a big smile on his face. In addition, later in the evening when he found out that it was my birthday coming up, he surprised me with a special yummy dessert (on the house!), with all the staff singing “Happy Birthday!” Oh, and did I mention that this was one of the best meals I ever had? What more can you ask for? Please visit Dairo at Flavia restaurant in Madrid-you won’t be sorry!

title_review: Very bad service and food as well as overcharging
review_preview: The Worst restaurant experience we had in Madrid. The first time we felt that we were hustled and tricked. We were greeted by an arrogant person who seemed to be the manager. Although we had a reservation, he made us feel as if he is...
review_full: The Worst restaurant experience we had in Madrid. The first time we felt that we were hustled and tricked. We were greeted by an arrogant person who seemed to be the manager. Although we had a reservation, he made us feel as if he is doing us a favor allowing us to eat at his restaurant. We wanted to order drinks, but their menus do not contain any information about soft drinks and beer so we asked the waitress to direct us to the correct information but she confirmed that the restaurant does not indicate or note the drink prices or which types of beer they have. I am not aware whether this is a legal practice to hide prices but it is definitely a practice that leaves the guests with a bad feeling. We asked her for information and she gave us wrong information. We ordered drinks and received the smallest soft drink bottles we ever had. Later they tried to charge us for drinks we did not order. Can you imagine that a small bottle of water costs 3.85 Euros? The came to the table offering us some what seemed to be cooked ham. We declined. Later we read other reviews claiming it is part of their practice to later charge extra money for that from the guest who never ordered it. There was a basket of dry bread on the table. We asked the waitress who answered "this bread is from today". It was dry and bad tasting. They did not provide us with fresh bread as in all other restaurants we visited especially those claiming to provide top quality food. The food is expensive and totally of poor quality compared to the prices you have to pay. 19.5 Euros for seafood pasta. In the menu it states that there is squid and lobster as well as clams, prawns and mussel. The waitress informed us the dish is served with the seafood peeled and ready to eat (as is customary). We received noodle soft overcooked pasta. We found 1 clam and zero lobster and zero squid. We did find some mussels and shrimps or prawns. We asked the waitress about it. She said the squid and lobster are not detected because they dissolved, according to her. We did not accept her explanation and asked her to check with the chef whether we received squid and lobster. Then another guy waiter who was very rude and aggressive approached us and stated that it is our fault we did not receive lobster because according to him we demanded peeled see food and lobster is neve peeled so we were not provided any lobster. I told him that we have had lobster before many times and we always received the lobster tail peeled and there is no issue to that, and furthermore they never advised us that they would not put any lobster as it is stated in the menu. Furthermore, he claimed we received squid but we do not know the difference between squid and pasta, and according to him we mistook the pasta which was actually squid. I have never heard such a ridiculous claim in my life and felt conned and cheated. In 30 years of eating seafood I have never heard that pasta is squid or can be confused with squid. Based on the interaction with the staff, It is clear to us that the restaurant intentionally cheated us and charged us for overcooked pasta without lobster and squid and hardly any clams.  The salad was also expensive, bland, unseasoned or under-seasoned and we paid around 14 Euros for it. They never apologized for there terrible performance and even proceeded to overcharge us in the bill possibly assuming we are dumb tourists that would be unaware of their "mistakes" in overcharging. Upon our insistence, they reluctantly proceeded to remove the overcharges from the bill. What a terrible experience, bad service bad food high prices and shady practices. I would never return to this terrible restaurant who does not appreciate its guests and tries to trick them. Horrendous place expensive and bad service and worse food.

review_preview: We were so entranced by the atmosphere that we visited here on both of our last two nights in Madrid-- short but most memorable visits full of conversation. Very smoky, small and unchanged for untold decades: posters, barrels of sherry, sepia-toned plaster and dusty bottles....
review_full: We were so entranced by the atmosphere that we visited here on both of our last two nights in Madrid-- short but most memorable visits full of conversation. Very smoky, small and unchanged for untold decades: posters, barrels of sherry, sepia-toned plaster and dusty bottles. A small range of sherries are served with a small range of snacks but the proprietress (we think) standing guard and posting commentary at the entrance, the wonderfully stoic bartender and guests from all over the world create unsurpassed atmosphere; the place is nicely lively at one moment then completely packed the next; smoky all the time - the only place in the world I have found cigarette smoke remotely tolerable. Viva Venencia!

review_preview: The guide books warn you this place is basic, with sherry the only option and a very limited range of tapas to nibble with it.  Thats all true.  Its also aimed at the locals, some of whom seemed to have been coming here (or perhaps...
review_full: The guide books warn you this place is basic, with sherry the only option and a very limited range of tapas to nibble with it. Thats all true. Its also aimed at the locals, some of whom seemed to have been coming here (or perhaps sitting at the same scruffy tables) for decades. So if you that's what you want, then you will enjoy the simple atmosphere, the smoky walls, the dim lighting, and the surpassingly good (and cheap) sherry and tapas.  Oddly enough, they speak Spanish; that seems to come as a surprise to some of the joyless folk who have given this place harsh reviews. But with a big smile, some pointing at what you want, a willingness to try new things, and some basic respect for the local people, and I think you will be fine and have a very unusual and valuable experience.

My spaghetti was average, nothing to write home about . Ditto with truffle pizza . But the wines and cocktails made up for the entree.  We were not aware of restaurants charging customers for bread and olive oil nor were we told about it at the restaurant when the waitress asked us if she could get some bread to the table when our order was being prepped. (Back home in US, that’s a complimentary dish ). Average food and pricey .

review_preview: Being a fan of Hemingway's writing, I sought out this bar in Madrid as one of his haunts during his several years in love with the city. Not much has changed here since he sat at one of these tables, drinking sherry with comrades. You...
review_full: Being a fan of Hemingway's writing, I sought out this bar in Madrid as one of his haunts during his several years in love with the city. Not much has changed here since he sat at one of these tables, drinking sherry with comrades. You have a choice from several styles of sherry; we chose an almontillado for its nuttier tones--for me manzanilla is too astringent--and sipped while admiring the dusty bottles behind the bar. Honor the request not to take photos; it harkens to the time when people came here to avoid being noted.

Mind you, I lived in Madrid and speak fluent Spanish and know a lot about sherry (have been a fan for 30 years) and had just come from Jerez but he was indifferent. I asked him what bodega it was from and he just said it's just sherry, period. Geez, thanks. The woman behind the bar was nicer. basically go to Jerez and visit a Tabanco like El Pasaje which is 100 times better. But if you are in Madrid only, sure, cool to stop in for a glass or two of sherry and some cheese/meats and read about the history but don't expect service with a smile or any hard to find sherry.

review_preview: We were staying across the street at the Gran Hotel Ingles and looked upon the storefront each time we entered and exited our hotel. Over cocktails at our hotel bar, we were told to not miss this place, and so glad we didn't. It's a...
review_full: We were staying across the street at the Gran Hotel Ingles and looked upon the storefront each time we entered and exited our hotel. Over cocktails at our hotel bar, we were told to not miss this place, and so glad we didn't. It's a time warp, dust on all the sherry bottles lining the back wall, this place in untouched. The bartender was very patient and knowledgeable, we had never tried Sherry so he guided us through journey of 3 different glasses. You get tapas w/ each glass, first olives, then nuts. We saw others with cheese and meats. They keep your tab total , which is far less than you'll spend anywhere else in Madrid, on the bar with chalk as you order. There are 5 sherries to choose from, nothing else. An experience to talk about long after you leave.

title_review: Authentic Bar with a Great History
review_preview: This is a bar steeped in history that still maintains its strict traditions from the early 1900’s.   It has a very rustic, traditional feel and the walls, photos, furniture and décor send you back in time.   No tips are accepted, no photographs are allowed and...
review_full: This is a bar steeped in history that still maintains its strict traditions from the early 1900’s. It has a very rustic, traditional feel and the walls, photos, furniture and décor send you back in time. No tips are accepted, no photographs are allowed and only sherry and water are served. We had two different types of sherry which were great (a sweet and not so sweet one – sorry, I am not a sherry drinker and cannot remember the exact types). We are very glad to have had a chance to visit and will do so again if we head to Madrid.

review_preview: You would think that with all the fantastic spanish food available everywhere in Madrid, why would someone want to have Italian food? It turns out that Flavia Restaurant & Bar has excellent Italian cuisine, in a nice and cozy atmosphere and in a location just...
review_full: You would think that with all the fantastic spanish food available everywhere in Madrid, why would someone want to have Italian food? It turns out that Flavia Restaurant & Bar has excellent Italian cuisine, in a nice and cozy atmosphere and in a location just a few steps away from Calle de Serrano, the equivalent in Madrid to New York's Fifth Avenue. The restaurant has a menu that caters to all kinds of diners, from carnivores to vegetarian, to gluten free to just mention a few. We went for dinner and had made a reservation (it was a Friday evening!) and the place was packed. Service was attentive, polite and efficient. We all ordered dishes to share and the waiter organized that the kitchen divided each shared plate into two portions on separate dishes, thus avoiding the usual complication of trying to divide the dishes at the table. The menu is filled with all kinds of delicious dishes, we decided to try some pasta and pizzas to share. We first ate our pizzas and then the waiter brought the pasta dishes piping hot from the kitchen. The wine list was very good having a good sellection of Italian and other wines. We selected a red primitivo (from Puglia region) that was superb. Desert was a delectable panna cotta and an exquisite espresso

We will return on our next visit to Madrid!

title_review: A great evening on the Manzanilla!
review_preview: I only started drinking 'proper' sherry about 2 years ago, with Manzanillla being my firm favourite. I had heard about this place even before that and thought it sounded interesting, but now as a sherry lover, and despite only spending one day in Madrid as...
review_full: I only started drinking 'proper' sherry about 2 years ago, with Manzanillla being my firm favourite. I had heard about this place even before that and thought it sounded interesting, but now as a sherry lover, and despite only spending one day in Madrid as a stop off, this was high on my places to visit. Lets get one thing straight, if you do not like sherry, dusty old shelves, old world charm and no nonsense service, then this probably is not the place for you. There are plenty of modern bars selling cocktails, fancy wines and exciting food, but this is NOT one of them. It is also not somewhere to go for a meal as tapas is all there is, and only a small selection at that.  Now, if you love sherry, or are open to giving it a fair chance, and want to drink it in unpretentious surroundings, with a small, but perfectly suited selection of tapas, then you really do have to check this place out. So you cant take photos, leave a tip or stroke the cat....so what!! If updating your facebook status with a photo is priority for you, best stay away. I for one can not wait to go back, and have already recommended it to anyone who will listen. This place is what it is, so please do not complain if after reading the reviews you still go, and expect it to be something it isn't

review_preview: This tucked-away sherry bar is a gem ----with lots of history attached. Unlike the output of  modern interior designers of bars and restaurants who strive for a "distressed" look, this interior is genuinely distressed. The only comparator I can think of is Gordon's wine bar...
review_full: This tucked-away sherry bar is a gem ----with lots of history attached. Unlike the output of modern interior designers of bars and restaurants who strive for a "distressed" look, this interior is genuinely distressed. The only comparator I can think of is Gordon's wine bar in Villiers Street, London: decades of tobacco stains on the walls and ceilings, plain wooden floor, crumbling plaster, rickety chairs to sit on, and all orders placed at the counter. We visited twice during our stay: once at 10pm after dinner when it was very quiet; once before dinner around 7pm when the place was heaving. You have to push your way through to find a chair or a table in the rear room and then push your way back to the bar to order your sherry ----which is the main point in coming. A very good range of excellent sherries drawn from large wooden casks (each having mysterious chalk markings ). We has mostly manzanilla,fino and oloroso---all of which were excellent and cheaper than other bars we visited. Nutrition is provided by a plate of olives. Strongly recommended provided you dont mind a Madrid rugby scrum: otherwise go at 10pm. Quite properly, the management do not allow photographs inside. Look out for the house cat Lola who is 18 and is content to sit on a customer's lap and watch the action.

Restaurant opens at 8.30.

We ordered 3 different pastas, all of which were inferior to what we would have considered just good. We will not go back. Our lesson, since this Italian did have a reasonable rating, not high, but reasonable, that in Madrid stick to Spanish food period.

title_review: Best meal we had in Madrid
review_preview: If you find yourself needing a break from Spanish cuisine do yourself a favor and try this little Italian place. The food was excellent as was the Sangiovese red we had with our pasta, the noodles were incredibly fresh, yum. We did not order the...
review_full: If you find yourself needing a break from Spanish cuisine do yourself a favor and try this little Italian place. The food was excellent as was the Sangiovese red we had with our pasta, the noodles were incredibly fresh, yum. We did not order the pizza but it looked and smelled fantastic. The staff tried very hard to make sure we were enjoying our meal and made the wine recommendation, the salad was excellent, the portions were generous. The restaurant is not very big and is on a small side street off Calle Atocha but you will know you are there when you see the Italian flag outside the door. Who would have thought that the best meal we would have in Madrid would be Italian food.

title_review: Best Italian Meal so far in Madrid!  Soooo good!
review_preview: Went for dinner last night and was very impressed with the food.  Very tasty. I love Italian food and I haven't been impressed with a lot of the restaurants here at all.  This is a small restaurant near Atocha/Anton Martín so firstly I would recommend...
review_full: Went for dinner last night and was very impressed with the food. Very tasty. I love Italian food and I haven't been impressed with a lot of the restaurants here at all. This is a small restaurant near Atocha/Anton Martín so firstly I would recommend you book. A friend and I shared pasta stuffed with salmon, tomato, vodka and cream and it was delicious. We then shared a mozzarella and pest pizza which was lovely too, followed by amazing homemade profiteroles. My not easy to please friend said it was the best Italian meal she has had in Madrid and I agree.....and we've been here for 5 years. The staff are relaxed. There is no pressure to finish and leave even on a busy Saturday night. We shared the 3 ample courses above and each had 4 glasses of wine and it came to 51 euros in total so great value too! Can't wait to go back and try the gnocchi in pesto sauce we saw the guy at the table next to us eating.

review_full: My boyfriend found this restaurant on trip advisor. We were staying on Calle Atocha so it was just a short walk away. The young guys who run it are fun but clearly take their food seriously. Our waiter (also one of the owners too I think) recommended a good wine for us. I had the tomato and mozzarella starter, which was a huge portion. A full giant mozzarella ball with huge slides of beef tomatoes in a lovely olive oil dressing. It could have easily been for two people. I had a pesto pasta main course and asked for some chicken to be added, which they obliged. Again, a massive portion! You won't leave this place hungry! Good atmosphere and definitely worth a visit!

title_review: Excellent Italian cuisine in central Madrid.
review_preview: Came upon this restaurant  by chance.  We were staying @ a nearby hotel on Paseo de Arte.Saw the Italian flag from the avenue and thought we would check it out.  Glad we did!We were the only ones in the place and the owner...
review_full: Came upon this restaurant by chance. We were staying @ a nearby hotel on Paseo de Arte. Saw the Italian flag from the avenue and thought we would check it out. Glad we did! We were the only ones in the place and the owner and a chef were the only other people in that evening. Owner was extremely friendly accommodating. Went over menu and made suggestions. Both our meals were exceptional! Since we were leaving on a 5 day tour the next morning but returning to Madrid the following week we again had our second meal @ this wonderful restaurant and again it was fantastic. Highly recommend....all fresh ingredients....fabulous desserts...if we are in Madrid again we certainly will return to Piccolo Diavolo. Viva Antonio!

title_review: Amazing! Coming from a seasoned food critique
review_preview: I have been working in the industry for 23 years now, and have never eaten something that was so delicious that I felt compelled to write a review immediately. I highly recommend the Pasta OFNI, created by the Madrid contrabassist,author, and philosopher Pablo M. Caminero....
review_full: I have been working in the industry for 23 years now, and have never eaten something that was so delicious that I felt compelled to write a review immediately.  I highly recommend the Pasta OFNI, created by the Madrid contrabassist,author, and philosopher Pablo M. Caminero. The chef personally came and checked in on every diner, and recommended the new dish.  It has such a wonderful neighborhood-feel, but is small and classy. The artwork they display is also very in touch with the overall decor.  Cannot recommend enough!

Great, attentive, but not intrusive service. Manager and waitstaff treated us as family.

review_preview: My husband and I loved this restaurant so much that I decided to do my first review here!If you want great Italian food with amazing service, come here! Our server John Paul and Manager Dayro took excellent care of us! My husband and I...
review_full: My husband and I loved this restaurant so much that I decided to do my first review here! If you want great Italian food with amazing service, come here! Our server John Paul and Manager Dayro took excellent care of us! My husband and I were in Madrid for a portion of our honeymoon and we wanted to go out to a local restaurant on our last night. Found Flavia through TA (thanks reviewers!) and we were able to make reservations with no problem on a Wednesday night. The restaurant was busy, but Dayro greeted us with a huge smile and sat us near the window. John Paul came by to our table and even though he spoke little English, it was not a problem! We were able to point at the menu with our choices (jlamon and caprese for appetizers, husband had the ravioletti ricotta with truffle cream and mushrooms, I had the house linguini, and a fruit tart for dessert--all were excellent!) and John Paul understood. He was attentive, but not overbearing, made us laugh, and had a fun attitude! My husband used Google Translate to mention to him that he was the best waiter he had ever met. When he read the message, his eyes lit up and he brought the message to Dayro and both came running back to the table with big smiles. We casually mentioned that we were on our honeymoon and this was where the real fun began! Dayro stepped away for a few moments when the music suddenly changed to a happy birthday song. From across the restaurant, he ran towards our table with a firework in hand. Dayro and John Paul surprised us with cheesecake (that I mistakenly thought was flan), and drinks for the rest of the night! We were treated like we were part of their family and found friendship with Dayro and John Paul. Thank you for making our last night of our honeymoon unforgettable! We hope to visit again one day!

Probably won't be going back here.

Simple food such as bread, cheese and salami are also available. This was a unique experience and we loved it som much we went back twice !

review_preview: Read about this place on an American website, prior to a visit to Madrid. The place took some finding, but boy was it worth it. Not being a typical sherry drinker, I was unsure about a positive drinking experience. I was there to see a...
review_full: Read about this place on an American website, prior to a visit to Madrid. The place took some finding, but boy was it worth it. Not being a typical sherry drinker, I was unsure about a positive drinking experience. I was there to see a way of life, going back to the days of the Spanish civil war. The room was dark and dusty, and looked like the cleaner had been sacked years ago. The barman's shirt looked like it could do with a good ironing, and he was not over enthusiastic about our arrival. Anyway, down to business. We ordered two number 3's from a list of 5 sherries. Number 1 is the palest, number 5 is the darkest. Whereas the number 3 was hardly memorable, it gave me time to study what was going on in the bar, and what was available. It was obvious that the drink to buy was the number 1, (Manzanilla) It was the cheapest too! I then spotted the best deal in Madrid, we bought a 5 sherry taster rack, (each) plus a rustic snack board of olives, nuts, chirozo and bread, all for 7.50 euros. Wonderful! As time went by, we mellowed completely, thoroughly enjoying a unique experience. As we left the bar, I had a definite stagger. I cannot wait to go back. The thought of drinking Manzanilla, whilst eating olives, in authentic Spanish surroundings is one to savour.

title_review: Unusual and unlike the ' other' place touristy place
review_preview: They do not speak English. At all. But you'll be sure to find someone drinking there who does  - at least a little. We went in the early afternoon - probably the worst time to be drinking sherry, which IS after all fortified wine. Did...
review_full: They do not speak English. At all. But you'll be sure to find someone drinking there who does - at least a little. We went in the early afternoon - probably the worst time to be drinking sherry, which IS after all fortified wine. Did the locals think it was a bad idea? Nah! But they are not wussy little tourists they are R.E.G.U.L.A.R.S. They stroll in about 12ish linger over their 3-4 glasses, taking their pick from the lighter, sweeter amontillado or the crisp dry manzanilla or the darker oloroso which wasn't available when we went. Tapas are limited in variety and basic - olives, bread and manchego, dried fish, slices of Iberian jamon, nuts. The owner is soft-spoken and quiet and when we went it was just him manning the bar and a crowd of 20 odd customers, most of whom have been coming here for 20-40 years ( yes, we found someone who spoke English and gave us a helping hand). The interior is dark and cool, a few old tables, mostly standing room. The hum of conversation is often pierced by laughter or a loud exclamation and regulars from other tables chip in with comments. You are the outsider - you know it, but it's reassuring that every time you meet a strangers gaze you see curiosity and a friendly smile. No hostility here - they accept you into a select group that comes together for the love of sherry, for sherry is the focus here. Dusty old bottles glint in the light of old old lampshades. The shelves behind the bar is lined with row upon row and you can bet one of them contains a genie.  Your bill is tabulated on the wooden bar counter in chalk. €13 for 6 sherries and a couple of tapas. Come for atmosphere, to see how the locals drink. Come because you want to snatch a glimpse of days that are past. But most of all, come for the love of Sherry.

title_review: Do you have to be rude to be real?
review_preview: It is as others have said very authentic feeling and certainly very uncompromising. The tapas are just traditional dried meat and fish in the main with bread and nuts etc. The service is also uncompromising with no concessions to you not knowing what they do...
review_full: It is as others have said very authentic feeling and certainly very uncompromising. The tapas are just traditional dried meat and fish in the main with bread and nuts etc.  The service is also uncompromising with no concessions to you not knowing what they do and how they do it. It reminded me of those Soho Chinese restaurants where you know the food must be good because they treat you so badly. At this place they have various rules and idiosyncrasies and seem to enjoy being slightly intolerant of your ignorance. We agreed that it was an interesting experience but not one we would necessarily want to repeat. Probably better for a drink...only Sherry, than for a Meal which is what we needed.  Not for the faint hearted but good fun for the moderately brave.

review_preview: First let me start by saying the only thing better than the food was the service. I was treated like family almost immediately after showing interest and appreciation for the food. Miguel works much of the front of the house and he is outgoing and...
review_full: First let me start by saying the only thing better than the food was the service. I was treated like family almost immediately after showing interest and appreciation for the food. Miguel works much of the front of the house and he is outgoing and knowledgeable.  The food was exceptional. A word of note though, the Spanish like their pasta a bit more cooked than traditional al dente that Italians and Americans prefer, so if you order pasta please advise your waiter how you prefer your pasta as they tend to serve the locals.  The food was all exceptional. I highly recommend the veal meatballs "albondigas" ... They were some of the  best I have had. The bolognese is also exceptional.  The pizza is traditional Neopolitan and some of the best in Madrid. But if there was a can't miss item it would be the burratta ... It is flown in from Naples and absolutely perfectly paired with sundries tomatoes and bread. It is amazing! I I highly recommend Flavia ... And the location is very near my hotel and Alcalá.

But the top of the line was the delicious pineapple with cinnamon and sugar. and they bring it just in time... in the middle of all the meat so it's refresh your mouth and just make you feel like you are in heaven! Regarding the price I think it's reasonable for all you can eat Meat. Thank you guys. next time we will come to madrid we will visit again.

title_review: Great Italian restaurant in the Heart of Spain!
review_preview: Just three months old and we happened to walk in because it looked so beautiful.  The food was delicious - we went twice in 2 days.  Dinner starts at 8:30 pm and they let us in early.  Great bottle of Italian wine, delicious clams in...
review_full: Just three months old and we happened to walk in because it looked so beautiful. The food was delicious - we went twice in 2 days. Dinner starts at 8:30 pm and they let us in early. Great bottle of Italian wine, delicious clams in white wine, garlic, butter sauce. Dessert - pure decadence. We met the owner who told us the Pastry Chef graduated the top of her class. He brought us a spectacular dark chocolate pastry. Pasta a la vongele, buffalo mozzarella salad, veal scallopine - every meal was absolute perfection. Great bread basket and ham plate delivered to the table while we looked over the menu. Everyone here was gracious, accommodating and a delight. If you like Italian food and a comfortable upscale environment this is perfect. Thank you Flavia for a wonderful experience! We will be back!

title_review: One of the best italian I have ever had!
review_preview: Great service. This restaurant was recommended by our hotel. It is very close to Retiro Park. We went there twice during our stay in Madrid and had pizza and pastas. The pepperoni pizza as well as the veal meatball tagliatella were memorably fantastic. The wine...
review_full: Great service. This restaurant was recommended by our hotel. It is very close to Retiro Park. We went there twice during our stay in Madrid and had pizza and pastas. The pepperoni pizza as well as the veal meatball tagliatella were memorably fantastic. The wine was also very reasonable at 3.50 euros a glass.  We didnt have any dessert or starters but all the mains we had were good; pesto pasta, gnacchi with peppers and tomatoes. The bill for 4 people came to about 100 euros. The mains were about 14-17 euros each. Nothing to complain. The staff was very accomodating when we showed up around 8 pm ( which is very early for Spain) for dinner. We had a few drinks while we waited as pizza can be ordered only after 8.30pm.

review_preview: We had a function to attend later in the evening and wanted to find a good Italian Restaurant to eat dinner. Wow what a find. Tucked down a small lane way, Flavia is a surprise in many ways. We entered thinking it would be a...
review_full: We had a function to attend later in the evening and wanted to find a good Italian Restaurant to eat dinner. Wow what a find. Tucked down a small lane way, Flavia is a surprise in many ways. We entered thinking it would be a traditional small Italian restaurant and were surprised to find a 3-level restaurant bar with live band. We didn't have a reservation but that was no problem and we were escorted to the quieter downstairs dining area. The menu was extensive as was the wine list and all fairly priced. A plate of fresh mortadella and breads was placed on the table (chargeable) and we devoured the mortadella in seconds. My wife chose fresh spaghetti bolognaise and myself the freshly made meat agnolotti ametricana. We both agreed it was some of the best pasta we had ever had. As we were leaving, the manager/owner asked if we would like to stay and enjoy the live music upstairs which if we did not have a prior engagement we would have as it sounded great, but we said we would be back.  The next day we went back fro lunch and he greeted us with a big smile and asked why we didn't come back last night! He really looked after us and made our final meal in Madrid special.

title_review: Little devil and a smiling angel
review_preview: Piccolo Diavolo (Little Devil) is situated on one of these side streets close to Atocha, Prado and Reina Sofía. It's cosy and intimate and quite small (30 covers perhaps). We were lucky to get a table on a late Thursday evening without a reservation. There...
review_full: Piccolo Diavolo (Little Devil) is situated on one of these side streets close to Atocha, Prado and Reina Sofía. It's cosy and intimate and quite small (30 covers perhaps). We were lucky to get a table on a late Thursday evening without a reservation. There was only one waitress, very friendly and smiling, especially considering the restaurant was full. An angel. Prices were reasonable (see photo of bill) although we didn't eat much. The pizza looked huge but we didn't have one. Instead, we started with "garlic bread", which really wasn't. It was "bruschetta", which is tomatoes, pesto and pecorino cheese  on toast. Fresh and subtle. Then, we had Fagottini. Fagottini (from "fagotto", meaning bundle; fagottini = little bundles) is a type of pasta, about the size of ravioli, and normally filled with some kind of vegetables. Here, they are filled with ricotta cheese and pears and served with a hint of amaretto sauce and almonds. Because of the pear, it tasted more like a dessert, and the portion was quite small, so I won't recommend it to anyone averse to sweet food, or is hungry! The other dish we had was "Chitarrine ai porcini con crema al tartufo". Chitarrine is a flat form of spaghetti, a narrower form of tagliatelle, but taste more like the former rather than the latter. Ours was served with porcini mushrooms and truffle cream. I think they make their own pasta and it was cooked al dente, the way pasta ought to be served. Portion, again, was a bit on the paucity side, so you may need to order something more than just this if you're having it as your main course. Taste was exquisite. In conclusion, I can safely recommend this "Little Devil" ;-) for the super waitress and the good food and if I fancy Italian in Madrid, this will be on my list.

review_preview: This place is nothing glamorous (as many others in this area of the city) but food is truly typical Italian. The dishes are simple (with some digressions on the usual themes, like the pasta with almond filling..) and the choice of pizzas quite limited. However,...
review_full: This place is nothing glamorous (as many others in this area of the city) but food is truly typical Italian. The dishes are simple (with some digressions on the usual themes, like the pasta with almond filling..) and the choice of pizzas quite limited. However, the ingredients taste fresh (I recommend any salad with buffalo mozzarella: simply delicious!) and that makes most of the choices worthwhile. As for the pizzas, you would be disappointed if you expected wooden-fired-oven-style pizzas. However, among all the ones I've tried in Madrid, this probably the best one. On the other side, the dessert offer definitely needs upgrading. Prices are reasonable but I recommend booking in advance on Friday/Saturday evening because of the limited number of tables.

review_preview: My family likes to find a pizza place for one of our first evenings out in any new city when we're on vacation, even in Madrid!This was a great location for us, just a 10-15 minute walk from our hotel toward the Real Jardin Botanico....
review_full: My family likes to find a pizza place for one of our first evenings out in any new city when we're on vacation, even in Madrid!This was a great location for us, just a 10-15 minute walk from our hotel toward the Real Jardin Botanico. It's tucked away down a little side street off Calle de Atocha (near Atocha Station), which makes it appear to be a bit of a hidden gem. It's a very cozy, friendly place with great service and DELICIOUS pizza. They had many things on the menu but we were just there for the pizza, and it was everything we could have asked for: fresh ingredients, great sauces and the perfect thin crust with airy, chewy edges. If you're lucky enough to be in Madrid and in the mood for some authentic pizza, this is a place not to be missed!

review_preview: How anyone not already  a convert to sherry could ever leave this place unconverted would be a mystery to me!  It must be unique, not just in Madrid but in the world.  Unchanged and undusted in decades, walls plastered with nicotine stained posters of Ferias...
review_full: How anyone not already a convert to sherry could ever leave this place unconverted would be a mystery to me! It must be unique, not just in Madrid but in the world. Unchanged and undusted in decades, walls plastered with nicotine stained posters of Ferias de Jerez dating back to the 1950's which would undoubtedly disintegrate if touched. And serving the most delicious sherry of all the classic types , all chilled, which in my book is a mistake, but it would invite mayhem to suggest it...! I think the warnings about unfriendliness are exaggerated, as are the obvious myths about why photography is banned. Taking photos in bars is a nasty habit dating back not much more than a decade, and any ban is greatly to be welcomed. Anyway who wants a photo of yellowing mouldering walls and a few barrels? You come here for the miraculous nectar produced from the Palomino grape. Unmissable.

title_review: One for the locals, I'd say, not the tourists.
review_preview: Quite a fascinating little place, long and thin. The smell is a bit musty and the walls look damp, but I'd say that adds to the character, along with the nicotine stained and peeling posters on the walls.The sherry is stored in big barrels...
review_full: Quite a fascinating little place, long and thin. The smell is a bit musty and the walls look damp, but I'd say that adds to the character, along with the nicotine stained and peeling posters on the walls. The sherry is stored in big barrels up against the bar wall. This is dispensed into 5 bottles - one for each type of sherry - then stored in a terracotta planter full of ice. We had 2 glasses each of Fino. It was lovely and at 1.7 euros a glass, we did not feel ripped off, since we were tourists. We arrived in the evening just as it was opening. We were the only tourists there, whilst a few locals came in. Our service was surly.  My wife was told quite firmly "no photos!" when she took her camera out. The locals got the usual free tapas on purchase, we got nothing both times. It's definitely worth one try when in Madrid, but that's it. I might use it again if I was passing, but I'd not search it out again.
